column1272: Bought item for my Cannon HF200 HD Camcorder.
column1273:
I am not a tech geek, so I cannot comment on the speeds and performance of this flash card. However, I bought this card to work with my Cannon HF200 HD Camcorder. I read quite a few reviews but did not see this mentioned about this card, and I could not read all six hundred of them, but for the HF200 this card will not record HD video on the Camcorders two highest settings(Which is why it gets only 3 stars from me). I was mislead a little bit becuase the Camera reccomends class 6 or higher, so I thought a class 10 would handle the job. But when trying to record in the two high HD settings, the camera says that the card will not support that resolution. It works fine on the 3 lower settings and displays over 12HRS of video time in LP. So if you have a Cannon HF200 and plan on taking nothing but high end HD video, this card will probably not work for you. Anyone reading this review, can maybe suggest another card that will? I will most likely keep it as most of the video I record will be in the lower settings. HD takes a lot of memory and I do not have an HD burner. I hope this helps the people with HF200. Thanks."
20110515"
column1276:
I have been using this brand for years now and it has never let me down. The price is affordable over other fancier brands. Last year I bought a Panasonic FZ100 and I needed a class 6 card. Then I came back and bought a class 10 card, and again choose this brand. No complaints here whatsoever!"
20110515"
column1278: the fastest but it will cost
column1279:
I bought this memory for the new Sony cybershot DSC-TX10 which came out early May 2011. It is a high defenition camara with HD video capability. BUT...the speed of capturing any video images or pictures is limited by the memory card. Slow memory card, poor video capture. That is why I purchased this card. It is the fastest on the market as of this date and can handle HD video. It is the second largest memory capacity of 64GB which is amazing that so much can be packed in such a small space. BUT...you pay for it (I paid about 150). However, I do not regret the purchase at all because it worked very well. Though not purfect. I noticed some choppiness when the the camare had to capture a fast moving vista as I was doing when shooting video from a moving vehicle.  There was still a little choppiness, but I had it on max HD at 1080X720 which in my opinion was very acceptable. Shooting moving subjects with a still background does great. Every still image I took was HD and camera pause was less than 1 sec as the image was stored in memory. The pauses in the camera after each picture is a result of how fast the memory card can store images. My older camera took longer than a second which can be an eternity. I can say that this memory stick, though not purfect, did very well. After all it is the fastest available to date. I love technology. If you want quick response to video capture, do not get anything less than this speed. And as for the 64GB capacity, you don't need to go higher (there's a 128GB out there) as I took about 45 min of video combined with about 100 pictures, all HD, I only used about 15 percent of the memory. I always download and save my images so as to free up the camara for the next oportunity shoot. This memory card was expensive but it was needed to take full advantage of HD."
20110514"
column1281: Won't record HD video as a Class 10 SDHC card should
column1282:
I bought this supposedly Class 10 SDHC card to use with my Canon T3i during my trip to Disneyland, knowing I'd probably want to take a lot of videos, and my current 4GB card probably wouldn't cut it. I'd done enough reading to know that if I wanted to record full HD videos, I should get a Class 10 SDHC card, and this one was the first result that popped up when I searched Amazon. It had enough decent reviews and I figured it was a good choice. WRONG. When I tried to record video onto it, after a couple seconds, my camera would display the message 'Movie recording has been stopped automatically.' ...Hmm. Weird. I popped in my 4GB PNY Class 4 SD card, and it recorded as much video as I wanted, for as long as I wanted. Popped this supposed Class 10 card back in, and movie record was stopped automatically again.If you just want to take pictures, then this card will do the job. But if you buy it expecting to be able to record HD video on it as a Class 10 card should, then spend a little more money and buy one of the more reliable big-name brands."
20110514"
column1285:
I purchased two of the Transcend 32GB Class 10 cards to use with my brand-new Canon HFS200 video recorder and couldn't be happier.  The cards performed flawlessly, giving me a combined total of ~4 hours of video at the highest possible resolution and frame rate; plenty of time to film my son's graduation from Marine Corps boot camp and all of the ancillary ceremonies.On a whim, I popped one of the cards into my Canon XSi DSLR.  Again at the highest resolution, the card would hold >5600 still pictures.While other reviewers may have carped a bit about the speed not being truly Class 10 SDHC material, it hasn't been a problem with my equipment.  In fact, I intend to buy a couple more to use as video camera 'extras' and for use with my DSLR still camera.EDIT 20 May 2011:  I received my two new 32GB SDHCs and field tested the speed on one in my Canon XSi.  In 'Continuous' shooting mode (where the camera will shoot ~3.6 frames per second) and the camera set to the highest resolution ('L' or 3072x2304 pixels), I took 38 photos before the camera seemed to take a short breather.  The camera slowed a bit to somewhere around 2 frames per second for 5 pictures, then picked back up to >3 frames per second for 17 more frames.  After 60 frames I ended the test.  I probably could have shot many, many more shots in 'Continuous' mode without much of an issue, but my battery was getting low...  I assume the slowing I experienced meant that the write speed couldn't quite keep up, but the camera never gave me a 'Busy' warning and completely stopped taking pictures like it would when using a Class 2, 4 or 6 card.  This card is plenty fast enough for me, since I don't plan to quit my day job and become a sports photog any time soon..."
20110513"
column1288:
After hearing lots of incompatibilities between different brands of cameras and SD cards, I was careful in searching for a decent (cheap and functional) SD card for my Nikon D3100 DSLR.  I was using an older Patriot 8GB SDHC class 6 card which worked fine, but I wanted larger capacity and faster speed.  The Patriot class 6 card works okay for video (both 720p and 1080p), but when I do burst shooting (3 pix/sec for D3100), I notice it does not always get me 3pps and buffer was full just after a few shots.  Even more noticeable with RAW+fine shooting option.  With this Transcend 16gb SDHC class 10, not only I get larger capacity for cheap (cheaper than most other brands), I got a speed upgrade over my older Patriot card as well.  Using Fine or Basic shooting option (no RAW), I can shoot around 6-10 pix before I notice a slowdown in writing into the SD card.  This is already a noticeable improvement for me.  The best of all is I've not lost any pictures or video with about 8gb of data I've shoot with the Transcend so far.  With so many compatibility issues out there, I can confirm this card works with my Nikon D3100 DSLR without any issues.It's no speed demon, but it work 100% for my purposes.  I am glad with my purchase."
20110512"
column1291:
Great deal. But it isn't as fast as I wanted--but that is what I wanted. No fault with the card. Good card, good price. I'm happy"
20110512"

Nothing to complain on this one although I did not conduct any rigorous testing and did not verify the speed. I used it in my new Canon HF M300 and tried FXP recording mode, everything looks fine."

column1315:
I think with things like this you're always taking a gamble.  In this case I'm using a Canon T2i and I bought this card for video shooting.  I already own a Patriot 16GB class 10 card which works beautifully and very consistently for me.  I bought this Transcend card based on value and reviews I read.  After having used it for a couple days I have to admit I'm disappointed.  For stills, it's fine.  For video?  Not so much.  It is constantly failing on me.  I'm also receiving a camera error when using this specific card in which I cannot shoot any video at all sometimes.  Despite formatting the card a few times, the problem persists.  This does not happen with the other cards I have from other manufacturers.  I can't say I know exactly what the problem is but I don't really care about that.  What matters is that it only happens with this card in the camera.  I bought this card so I could shoot more video with the greater storage capacity.  Needless to say, I think I'm going to just get another Patriot card at 32GB and try that while keeping this card for stills at least.  Nothing wrong with it for that."

I would have given it an overall 5 stars, but every now and then when it gets close to full it will stop recording and say 'recording has stopped' even though it is not quite full.  It has happened once when it was not full at all.  But for the price and how much I use it, I am very happy with this card.  I would definitely get another one."

After buying one of these off of eBay not long ago, and finding it was a fake, 3.1gb SD card. I was very pleased to receive this one and it work wonderfully. I bought it for my son's Wii for storage of the Wii Ware games you download with points. It arrived fast, was in great condition.Thank you"
20110507"
column1366:
This type 10 SDHC card is actually a fast memory. I did  a writing speed test transferring a 700MB file to the card and compare with a and old type 4 SDHC card.Results:- Type 10 write time :50 sec- Type 4 Write time : 1 min 48 secOf course this is not a scientific test, certainly the card writer and the communication bus could be the bottle neck, but at least twice faster is big gain, plus the card is actually dirty cheap.Ricardo"
20110506"
column1369:
I never receive my order. I have tried to contact by e-mail  two times but no responses.I have been a long time customer and bought a lot items.Your service is not good any more. sorry, in the future I will never buy again from you."
20110506"
column1372:
I bought this card for use with a GoPro HD960 video camera.  In specification the card meets and exceeds the needs of this device (class 4 needed vs. class 10 of this product).  I tested the card on a few short videos when I received it and all seemed to work fine.  Then I took some longer videos during a ski trip.  The first few were ok, but after a certain point the files were all corrupt.  I tried several things to recover them with no success.  I then re-formatted the card and started again.  Same result...  After a certain amount of written data, all the files were corrupt.  I have consulted with GoPro tech support and they indicated they are sure this is a bad card.  I am returning this. I am thinking of going with a 16Gb Sandisk.  It seems that Sandisk reviews are better and that 32Gb cards are not as reliable in general.  This is just my personal opinion after reading lots of reviews on Amazon."
20110506"
column1375:
I've been using this in my camera with no problems.  You can't really beat this performance at this price.  I don't exactly expect the same level of reliability you might find in sandisk memory, but for a camera I think the risk is acceptable."
20110506"
column1378:
SD card great and works as expected.The frustration free packaging was far from it. Over sized cardboard envelope and a super hard to open plastic container that need a knife, a screwdriver and pliers to get the SD card out..... far from frustration free.Again... good SD card."
20110506"
column1380: Class6 and class10 SD memory cards
column1381:
I purchased both Transcend class 10 and class 6 8GB SD memory cards.  They have worked without any problems and were very reasonably priced."
20110506"
column1384:
if you buy a class 6 card along with this onedon't just open the packages and set them down. Mark EACH ONE with Perm Marker so you'll know which one is class 10 and class 6. There aren't any identifiers so you can determine which is which. Popped it in the camera and it worked just fine.comes with a plastic case which is nice."
20110504"
column1387:
My Canon camcorder refuses to recognize this card as Class 10.  A warranty replacement (direct from Transcend) suffers from the same problem.  When I use the 'info' feature on the camcorder, my 32GB Class 6 Kingston card is recognized as Class 6, but the 32GB Class 10 Transcend card isn't recognized as Class 10 (or any other speed, for that matter).  Result: the camcorder refuses to record in hi-def to the card, making it largely useless.Avoid Transcend if possible, and go with another brand like Kingston."
20110504"
column1390:
This card is an excellent value, fast class 10 speed, high capacity at 16GB, and reliable performance. I would buy this card again."
20110504"
column1393:
Started having problems with my canon G9 reading this card. Getting a 'Memory Card Error' message.Working with Sandisk for a replacement but noticed during this process that the Class 10 card as advertised actually reads 'Class 6' on the card.Not really sure if I woud notice the difference but it would be nice if I received the card that was advertised on amazon."
20110503"
column1395: Transcend 32 GB=Good Price for a large amount of memory.
column1396:
I bought this product for a Canon Digital Camera that takes HD Video.  My 16 Gig chip ran out too quickly when I was taking video so I wanted more memory. So far this chip has performed very well.  My pictures download almost instantly and the video keeps on going.  The other chip brands want an arm and a leg for anything over 16 gigs so I was pleasantly surprised at Transcend's reasonable price. As far as customer service, the product came quickly and in good condition.  The shipping price was either free or negligible, I can't remember...but I know I wouldn't have bought it if the shipping made it as expensive as the other chips."
20110503"
column1398: Bad card, didn't FIT Canon SD870
column1399:
I ordered this card looking to using it for my son's first baseball game.  It came on time, BUT when I tried to insert it (removing the old 4gb card) the card would jam.  I got it in, but then it would not eject...I had to forcibly remove it with tweezers.  Yes, it was aligned correctly...the issue seemed to be the thickness/manufacturing tolerances."
20110503"
column1402:
I was a little hesitant to buy this card to use in my camera, because some people around the internet said it took a few seconds to snap pictures, but after reading a lot of the reviews and doing my research, I took the plunge.The card has not let me down. It takes pictures fairly quickly, and I was able to plug it into my camera right away and start using it, and then plug it into my computer and continue using it, and it worked perfectly with both."
20110503"
column1404: Do the math - 10% failure - Is your data worth more to you than $12?
column1405:
This may be the cheapest and it may save you $12 over other brands but please ask yourself how much is the data you are putting on it worth?  The data I trusted to this POS was in my eyes priceless...but the recover will only cost a little over $150.  At this point there are 44 1-star reviews and most of them deal with data loss.  BELIEVE IT!  Do the math...there is almost a 10% failure rate based on reviews and pay an extra 10-15 bucks for a better product!"
20110502"
column1408:
I bought it for my Sony CX160 HandyCam as a backup memory card to its in-built 16GB memory. I have shot about 50 mins of videos in FX mode (that is, HD @ 60i which is second best in terms of picture quality iny my Sony HandyCam) so far. FX mode, for me, is the ideal mode for shooting day-to-day videos in super clear HD video. The memory card has worked with absolutely no issue. I will try on PS mode (60p 28 Mbps); but I am sure it won't let me down. Its been just about a week though. But I am very happy with it so far. I would definitely recommend it for anyone who wants about 90 mins of HD (1080i) video."
20110502"
column1411:
Have always had good luck with Transcend cards. All have been reliable and have good transfer speed. Class 10 works well for movies."
20110501"
column1414:
I purchased two of these cards because they were at a reduced price. I've never used Transcend cards before so figured I'd give them a shot and if they weren't up to par with my others, at least I didn't spend a lot for them. They seem to be okay in regards to write speed when I use them in my DSLR but are pretty slow when downloading through my card reader. I don't have that problem with either my 8GB Sandisk or Kingston cards which are Class 6 and Class 10 cards. All of those are pretty fast to write to and pretty fast when downloading. I have mixed feelings about the Transcend cards. The price was very good but the download speed falls short. The cards are not horrendous but the old adage 'you get what you pay for' definitely applies."
20110501"

I don't normally do much video with these cameras but - I look forward to the opportunity when race season opens up."

Figured it would be sub-par being an off-brand, but it performed just fine.  I do photography and video for a local racetrack and needed the 16h 10speed to do higher resolution video and didn't have any problems."
20110426"
column1450:
I have two of these cards and bought them to use with a Canon 60D. My camera manual calls for class 6 or better. I thought I was saving money buying the transcend Class 10 for less than the SanDisk Class 6. This card is not capable of recording HD video on the 60D. It is not fast enough. After a couple seconds of shooting video the camera shows an ons creen indicator that looks like a buffer filling and ceases recording.There is something everyone buying SD cards should know:'Even though the class ratings are defined by a governing body, like  speed ratings, class speed ratings are quoted by the manufacturers and not verified by any independent evaluation process.'Long story made short this card is far slower than the SanDisk Extreme HD Video 16 GB SDHC Class 6 Memory Card (SDSDRX3-016G-A21). I had to demote both of these cards for use with point and shoot cameras.Basically pay no attention to class when choosing a SD card, instead look at the read / write speeds."
20110425"
column1453:
Bought this SD card with high expectations and was quite disappointed when i received it.  When used in my Canon DSLR it is not able to keep up with the camera when i take pictures in burst mode and i take a lot of pictures at once.  I also use the same camera for videos and with this card i am sometimes unable to take videos because recording stops automatically because the transfer rate is too slow.  I have had better experiences w/ a lower storage capacity SD card rated as a class 6."
20110425"
column1456:
Card works well;allows storage and transfer of approx 5 hours of standard video with no problem. (It would hold more but that's the max we can finish in one day.) More convenient than storing on camera hard drive.  We bought two so that there is no waiting for transfer if more than one run has to be captured.  Transfer is not lightning fast but that is most probably our server, not the card.  Well-priced for the amount of data that it holds.  Paid for itself by increasing efficiency of transfer!"
20110425"
column1459:
So far these have been holding up quite well.  I don't know that I can give an adequate review on these but they have been quite a fast addition to my camera bag.  Handles video well and has been taking the regular abuse that I've been handing it."
20110425"
column1461: 20 MB/s = too slow for me (in D7000)
column1462:
Bought 2 of these and returned them after seeing how slow they are in my D7000. To be fair: I'm shooting RAW and I'm shooting weddings and events. For someone with more standard use 20 MB/s might be okay.Even with compressed RAW and just 12-Bit it was like this: 5-6 clicks without delay then I had to wait about 3 seconds for every following click.I bought 2 SanDisk 32GB cards with 30 MB/s then (also labeled class 10 but this doesn't mean much - compare MB/s). They were about twice the price of the Transcend but it's a huge difference: 8 clicks without delay then a click every second.Again, if you're using the card in a SLR for vacation, landscape etc or video it's absolutely fine - fast enough. If you're using it for shooting events (or worse: sports) then pay more and buy something faster or you will likely miss some shots while waiting for the card to be ready again."
20110424"
column1464: Big card at a very reasonable price.
column1465:
This SD card at 16GB is very high capacity, allowing me to shoot RAW+JPG and store lots and lots of photos. Transfer speeds are very good, and the price was impressive. Delivery took a little longer than I had hoped, but it wasn't too bad. All in all, a very good value."
20110424"
column1468:
I bought this card for use in a Canon T2i. I was attracted by the speed, size and price. Unfortunately, the writes to this card cannot keep up with the 1080p video footage. Almost every time that i shoot footage, the camera must stop recording because the buffer becomes full and cannot write to the card quickly enough. This is problematic for getting those moments you don't want to miss...For shooting stills, even with burst rates of RAW files, it writes fast enough. No complaints there. I'll be searching for another, faster card though, to use with video footage."
20110424"
column1471:
I now have two of these memory cards and both are working well.  I use one in my Panasonic camcorder and one to capture my slides using a Wolverine Film to Digital Converter."
20110424"
column1474:
My school just got new HD tapeless cameras, so I had to buy an SD card to use them. Twenty-five dollars got me a class 10, 16GB card. AWESOME!! It has about 90min of record time on HD and more than twice that on standard def.The only thing I didn't like was it didn't come in a plastic case. So many people in my school leave their SD card cases at the bottom of the camera bag, I just snagged one from there ;p"
20110423"
column1477:
I use this card on a Canon Rebel T2i. The camera has been with me for almost a year. I have used it for underwater photography and videos (when scuba diving), at the summit of Mount Baker (2 F), and during regular use. The card has been nothing but stellar. I took plenty of photos and videos, at full resolution, and has worked flawlessly. I even downloaded the updates for the firmware for the camera directly into the card, no problem. I'm very happy with my purchase."
20110423"
column1479: shorted and deleted all of my pictures
column1480:
This sd card worked well for a while then over the past few months I would see 'Memory card error' on my camera more frequently. One day on vacation, I turned my camera on and lost 1000 photos we had taken on vacation. We had to bring the card to a data recovery place and pay $200 to retrieve our photos!!Save $200, your photos and the headache and buy another memory card!!"
20110423"
column1483:
This was my first sd card for my first dlsr camera so I have no frame of reference to compare it to.  All I know is that I have not had any problems with it.  I have not used it for any movies, just taking pictures.This card was cheaper than others I was looking at.I am planning on buying a second one.  I probably will get a larger one though.A quick note about SD cards if it is your first for a DSLR:  I decided I wanted to take photos in RAW format which means the file sizes are considerably larger than jpegs.  This 8gb card can only hold about 250 RAW photos.  It can hold considerably more jpegs (don't quote me but I want to say over 1000 or something crazy)."
20110423"
column1486:
I bought this for use with a Canon FS400.  It writes, it reads...what more can I say?  Knowing me, I'll probably not ever take it out of the camcorder unless it stops working.  I'm mostly amazed that $50 today will get you 32gb.  The last SD card I bought was for a digital camera... 2GB for $50."
20110422"
column1489:
SD specs state that class 10 cards must guarantee 10MB/sec transfer speeds in various conditions, so it should exceed this out of the box under ideal conditions. This product's advertised speeds are 'up to 20MB/sec' (which usually means reads).Under diglloydTools DiskTester on my MBP, which can usually come pretty close to capping various flash device speeds:Using test size of 2GB, 4MB at a time at start (0%), within a 30.2GB test file.Iteration 1: writing...15.2MB/sec, reading...19.6MB/secIteration 2: writing...15.6MB/sec, reading...19.7MB/secIteration 3: writing...15.6MB/sec, reading...19.7MB/secIteration 4: writing...15.7MB/sec, reading...19.7MB/secIteration 5: writing...15.7MB/sec, reading...19.7MB/secSo under good conditions (out of the box, large file transfer), I'm able to hit their advertised speeds, and both reads/writes are well above what is required for the spec. This agrees with several other reviews that the card is fast, with some numbers to back it up."
20110422"
column1492:
I just bought a new digital SLR camera and my brother-in-law recommended this card.  The price for the value was excellent.  The card easily transfers photos and videos between my camera and my laptop."
20110421"
column1494: Works for my needs, not super fast but plenty for HD video
column1495:
Didn't spend a whole lot of time critiquing the card, when shooting action on my T2i it slows a bit after 15 shots but HD 1080p/24fps seems to work fine. No complaints, my main use is shooting family stuff."
20110421"

The first of these cards I got was malfunctioning, where as every few seconds of using it for video on a Canon T2i the camera would stop recording because the card couldnt keep up. I returned it for a replacement, and this one hasnt had that problem at all! Great speed, huge space, and great pricing for only about 50 bucks. Reccomended!"

This was a great price and it's high quality. Came quickly, and operates perfect.Nic Coventry | The Recovering Banker"

column1503: Good storage for a casual user
column1504:

20110420"
column1506: Excellent value and function for my needs
column1507:
I bought an extra 16GB Transcend Class 10 SDHC for my GoPro HD camera.  I plan a 'semi-long' motorcycle trip over Memorial Day weekend this year (VT-Gettysburg-Washington,DC-and return).  Using a 16GB will allow a total of 180 minutes of recording time at high resolution - This will, along with a still camera, allow me to bring home a good record of the trip.  Shooting in short segments has worked well in the past.Amazon shipped this card quickly and for a price I would have a hard time beating.  A Class 10 card has a read/write speed of 80Mbits/second and a rating of 66x.  Now having a few of these will prove cost effective for my purposes!"

Great when taking long trips and you don't have access to your laptop to transfer the pictures from your 8 Gb card daily"

Tenia temor de comprarla porque hay memorias que no trabajan con todas las camaras pero al final me e decidido. Buena compra Funciona perfectamente."

column1521: Buen tamaño, pero la velocidad no es la esperada

Sin embargo la realidad es que la velocidad de la tarjeta no es la esperada, deja mucho que desear y no pude utilizarla para lo que habia pensado en un principio. La dejo en mi poder, más por aprovechar su espacio que por su velocidad."

column1530: 3 out of 4 cards corrupted permanently. Terrible cards. Do not buy.
column1531:
I've never had a single card failure in the last 7 years until I bought 4 of these cards of which three completely failed. These are obviously they worst cards I've ever purchased and will never buy any product from Transcend again. Samy's Camera in LA no longer stocks Transcend due to their high failure rate.I wish I knew that before I bought these.Luckily, I backed up the cards to the second slot in my D7000, but since I had two cards fail within a hour, one card was lost and is now in data recovery service's hands. Hopefully, they can recover the photos. I will only buy Sandisk from now on. How stupid of me to go cheaper on cards when I have 50K worth of camera equipment. I'll never make that mistake again."

Was also interesting to see it was faster than my usb card reader when I tried to benchmark it.  The case didn't try to delaminate when flexed, and the lock slide did not move when inserted into the camera like some brands.  This wont apply to 99% of the people out there, but users trying to use CHDK on their canons, the bootloader wont work on anything larger than 4gb I found out. column1558:
I was looking for a high capacity SDHC Card at an affordable price and found the Transcend 32 GB Class 10. It the best buy for a SDHC card in its category. It's better to have a high capacity card than a couple of less capacity cards; it beats changing cards and fearing you might run out of place too soon. This card is a class 10 so it is very fast in transferring the data in and out, remember the higher the 'Class' the better response you'll get. Remember don't be blinded by big name brands, open your eyes to effective productivity."

column1561:
I've been using SD cards for a while now (and MMC cards before that....) but when I bought my new Canon SX30IS camera last year, I knew that I'd need a big and fast SD card for it.  I chose this 16GB Transcend and have not been disappointed.  It's large, quick and has been good for me so far.  My camera takes HD video and this card keeps up just fine.  Class 10 is the way to go, and I doubt that I'd buy anything slower considering the price differences.My biggest problem is that I can let too many pictures build up on the card, so when I finally download them it takes me forever to organize them, which is no fault of the card.  :)I've used a smaller (4GB) Transcend SD card in one of my other digital cameras and it's been fine for years, so I felt good going with the same brand for my new camera."
20110413"
column1564:
Received in original packaging.  Obviously new.  Haven't tried them with my cameras yet, but sure they will be fine."
20110413"
column1566: Speed, size, and price - great sweet spot
column1567:
I'm just starting into digital photography, and had been working with a class 4 card.  My DSLR's continuous shoot operation delayed about 2 seconds between shots with that card, owing, I assume, to its slow write speed.I got this card instead, and that delay has shrunk to somewhere between half a second and one second.  This is great, since most of the time I'm trying to capture a smile on an infant's face, and he's less than cooperative about holding poses!  The 16 GB of space doesn't hurt, either - I could shoot over a thousand raws on this card alone.  Overall, I'm very satisfied with this purchase."
20110412"
column1570:
This is a good card.  I can snap off almost 27 JPG images in burst mode without my cache filling up with this card.  It is reliable,....no corrupt issues or anything like that.  Definitely glad I bought the 16GB option as the movies taken from PEntax KR are kind of on the LARGE file side of the spectrum.Either way, its hard to go wrong with this card."
20110412"
column1573:
I purchased this memory card to use it with my new GoPro HD camera.  I was a little nervous because I've read that the GoPro cameras can be finicky about which memory cards they work with and Transcend is not among the memory card brands that are recommended by GoPro.  However, the price seemed really good for a Class 10 card of this size, so I decided to give it a try.I am happy to report that the card seems to work fine with my GoPro HD.  I've typically been recording at the 720p60 setting, which GoPro lists as having a 15 Mbit/s data rate.  I've also used it on the 960p30 setting, which is listed as having a 12 Mbit/s data rate."
20110412"
column1575: So far so good. Awesome Price.
column1576:
Bought this for my Playsport Kodak camcorder. So far everything works well and gives me over 2-3 hours of video recording at 720p 60fps setting. It hasn't failed on me yet, but the transfer speed to computer is pretty slow. However for the price you pay for this compare to other similar products, this one is definitely worth it. I will update in the future in case if it ever fails on me (highly doubt it)."
20110412"
column1579:
I bought this because we needed more storage in our Wii.  We had a 1 GB card but that was mostly filled - we've purchased a number of downloadable games and hardly had any space to download any more games or demos.Moving the content from one card to another was a minor chore: first I inserted this card into the Wii, turned on the Wii, and moved (not copied) everything from system memory to this card.  I then turned off the Wii, inserted the old SD card, turned the Wii on, and moved as much as I could from the old SD card to the Wii.  Powering down the Wii, I inserted this card again, turned on the Wii, moved everything from system memory to this card...over and over until the old SD card was empty.  Phew!Now that everything's copied the card works as expected.  We can launch directly from the card and all thumbnails show up like they should.  No problems with this card and the Wii.Note that SD cards larger than 2 GB require Wii system menu 4.0 or higher to work.  If you've been doing system updates as they come out you'll be fine (we have version 4.3 right now) but if your Wii isn't connected to the Internet you'll have to update your system manually; see Nintendo's site for instructions.As an aside, Amazon's frustration-free packaging is great.  This card was in a plastic SD card protective case, which was in a thin cardboard envelope along with instructions and warranty information.  I unzipped the envelope, recycled it, and I was ready to go."
20110411"
column1581: Great memory at a great price!!
column1582:
going from a 2 Gig Class 4 to a 16 Gig Class 10 is a big difference. More storage and faster between shots.it's worth it."
20110411"
column1585:
My fiance and I have had the opportunity to takemany memorable pictures and this helps to take many more."
20110411"
column1588:
This SD card operates as advertised.  Using it for video recording and continually removing it from device and uploading/downloading data without any loss so far."

Does great loading up and getting to the next picture without having to wait.  I have been using it now for a few weeks and haven't had any trouble.  These bigger GB cards are 'Getting Cheaper and Cheaper'!"

This card is a Terrific deal for the price. Works great so far for class 10, but have not used it for video. I am sure it will work just fine for video as other people have used it without  any complaints. One of the best things about this card is the fustration free packaging thru Amazon."
20110409"
column1600:
Card works as intended. Transfer rate climbs above anything over around 500 MB. Below that size, transfer rate is about 15MB/s, above that (up to 8GB), the transfer rate is about 17. Hasn't improved my camera performance, but it downloads to the computer a lot quicker."
20110409"
column1603:

20110409"
column1606:
so far so good. great product, works great in my Nikon d3100 can I take ton of pictures and videos"
20110409"
column1609:
The memory card does what it supposed to do.The service is the important part.Amazon is a very well run company."
20110408"
column1612:
When used with my Sanyo HD camcorder, this can store up to 2.5 hours of 1080p -- no complaints there.I benchmarked this card with my Ubuntu desktop. Reads came out at 20 MB/s on average, but the average write speed was a modest 5 MB/s. I'm not sure if it's a problem with my USB stack or with the card, but if you ask me something's not right with that speed. I remember reading that this card handles 16 MB/s write speed, but my PC can't hit it very well.Here's a link to a screenshot, if Amazon lets me post it: [...]"
20110408"
column1614: Could not transfer all files successfully
column1615:
On both Linux and Windows computers I had problems transferring some files to this card.  There were certain files that failed every time.  I thought that there might be a problem with the files themselves, so I tested transferring them to a SanDisk 16GB SDHC, and it worked without a problem.Many times when I tried to transfer files to the Transcend card in Windows, it would be halfway through the file transfer and then I would get a pop-up message saying that the transfer had failed, followed immediately by a notification from the operating system that a new disk had been inserted.  It was as if the card's connection to the computer would somehow drop out sporadically in the middle of the transfer.  The odd thing was that this only happened with certain files, and it happened consistently.  It seemed to have no relationship to the size of the file, since there were plenty of larger files that I was able to transfer successfully.  But as I mentioned before, the same files transferred just fine to my SanDisk card.Maybe the card I had was just an anomaly, since this product seems to have pretty good reviews overall.  Either way, I returned the card and traded it for a SandDisk card.  My first experience with Transcend left a bad taste in my mouth, and I wasn't anxious to find out whether it was coincidence or not."
20110408"
column1617: Nice value, Works Fine for HD Video on My Kodak
column1618:
It works fine for HD video (1920 x 1080p) on my Kodak PlayFull.Nice value!"
20110408"
column1620: Avoid Transcend brand for HD video with Canon DSLR !
column1621:
The reason I am scoring this card is based on DSLR HD Video only -I currently use a Canon 60D that I bought in December and I bought a 16 gig class 10 Transcend card. The card has been fine for photography but I noticed I kept receiving errors when trying to shoot HD video. I assumed the problem may have been I needed a larger card. I decided to order a larger card, but upon researching and trying out the various cards I already had more I have realized that the problem is with the Transcend brand itself. For some  odd reason even if it's a class 10 (which according to Canon anything higher than class 6 will work for HD video) it crashes when shooting video. However, when using even a 4 gig class 6 SanDisk card, HD video shoots just fine. Altho the value of this card is awesome, I am disappointed that I have to return this item for a more expensive SanDisk card in order to shoot HD video.So in a nutshell if you are using a Canon DSLR with  HD video --DO NOT BUY THIS CARD, IT WILL STOP YOUR  VIDEOS WHILE RECORDING AND GIVE YOU ERROR MSGS! So far the only brand I know that is working with the Canon HD video recording is SanDisk, but those are the only two brands on hand I had to test it out."
20110408"
column1624:
I have a Sony NEX VG10 Video camera and needed a larger (relatively fast card to capture full HD) I have a number of 8 gig class 6 cards but find that it is inconvenient to swap out the cards while in the field doing nature footage.  This works quite well.  (PS. Have you ever dropped an SD card in the woods and tried to sort it out from all the leaves and such or in to the water?)"

column1821: SAME shooting speed as SanDisk Extreme III 30MB/sec. on Nikon D90 & D7000
column1822:
This video review is misleading and a fraud. But that's only a bad thing for SanDisk as this Transcend card is literally more than 99% as fast as the most expensive SanDisk card you can buy for a Nikon D90. Hell, this video is the reason I bought the SanDisk card.In the video review where he states '...The difference is the SanDisk card can capture 100 photos at fine resolution in 24 seconds. The Transcend card captures 66 photos in the same time/resolution' he is lying. I too have a Sandisk Extreme III card, a Transcend Class 10, a Transcend Class 6 card and a Nikon D90. I repeated this frame rate test at several resolutions. At EVERY resolution, there is EXTREMELY LITTLE frame rate difference between these cards. The truth is that even Transcend Class 6 cards offer essentially the same frame rate at the same resolution as the most expensive SanDisk card you can buy. The ONLY way you can get a D90 to shoot at maximum advance rate for 100 shots (without any buffer lag) is to drop to a low resolution and AS LONG AS YOU ARE RUNNING TRANSCEND CLASS 6 OR HIGHER, YOU WILL GET THE FASTEST FRAME RATE A NIKON D90 OR D7000 CAN MUSTER.I also own a Nikon D7000 that shoots at a substantially faster maximum advance AND writes MUCH larger files. At highest resolution of RAW + Fine Large jpeg, the difference between this Transcend Class 10 card, the SanDisk Extreme III and a Transcend Class 6 card is insignificant. We're talking about approximately 0.2 frames difference in a 4-second burst at Continuous High advance. All cards burn down the buffer in less than 2 seconds and then you are in jerky buffer-restricted advance at the same rate regardless of card.Food for thought: SanDisk marketed their Extreme 30MB/second cards as BOTH Class 6 and Class 10 at different times. They are the same cards. The TRUE difference between Class 6 and Class 10 is, wait for it... MARKETING. Wonder why Transcend Class 6 cards cost about the same as their Class 10 cards? Probably because they perform the same and likely ARE the same...This and the Transcend Class 6 card get 5 stars because they are literally over 99% as fast as the SanDisk '30MB/s' cards at a fraction of the price. Do NOT waste your money on SanDisk cards. They do not improve frame rate over Transcend Class 6 or 10 cards nor do they transfer to computer any faster. I'd only give the SanDisk cards 2 stars because they perform well but are EXTREMELY overpriced."
20110323"

Recorded pics and video are great quality, no issues whatsoever.  THIS CARD IS A GREAT VALUE!"

column1837:
I purchased the 32gb class 10 Transcend card because it received better reviews than Transcend's class 6 version, even though my camera mfr. specifies that the max speed it will support is class 6.Upon receipt, I tested the Transcend with H2TestW. Yes, it does technically qualify as class 10 because H2TestW reported a write speed of 16.3 mb/sec and a read speed of 18.2 mb/sec. However, the write speed is barely higher than a 4gb class 6 Sandisk card (15.5 mb/sec) which I also own. This tells me that what Sandisk labels as class 6 would qualify to be a class 10 card.Incidentally, Transcend does not appear to be as good a Sandisk cards in general. As a comparison:Sandisk 4gb class 6 came in at a write speed of 15.5 mb/sec and a read speed of 18.4.Transcend 4gb class 6 came in at a write speed of 11.2 mb/sec and a read speed of 14.8.My observation is that Transcend produces results only about 72% that of Sandisk for cards with the same specifications.A note on my tests: I probably have a fast card reader and other stuff on my desktop because using the same test on a notebook produced significantly lower results."

column1848: Barly Performs to Industry Standard - NOW DEAD!
column1849:
I purchased this product on two points, Class 10 & price.Although the price is amongst the cheapest out there, if you want quality in speed, you need to look closer.Here is a break down of the industry standard 'Class' ratings:  * SDHC Class 2: 2 MB/sec (16 Mbit/sec)  * SDHC Class 4: 4 MB/sec (32 Mbit/sec)  * SDHC Class 6: 6 MB/sec (48 Mbit/sec)  * SDHC Class 10: 10 MB/sec (80 Mbit/sec)This memory card being Class 10 means it has to achieve a minimum sustained write speed of 10MB/s.  This card does just that.I ran a benchmark using ATTO Disk Benchmark [...].  I compared it to another brand card, (16GB Class 6).  Although this card does what it's rating says it is suppose to do, the 16GB card did better at a lower Class.This cards Class 10 maximum Write Speed was just over 11MB/s and Read Speed was about 15.5MB/s.In contrast, the Class 6 more expensive card I used to compare, its Write Speed achieved about 14.3MB/s and a Read Speed of about 15.8MB/s.So if you want a product that does 'just' what it's suppose to do for a cheap price, this is the card you want.  But if you can afford a little more, you can do better with a more 'name brand' card....in my opinion.Happy recording!-------EDIT EDIT EDIT-------I've been using this memory card in my Fujifilm HS20EXR.  It's performed flawlessly until just now.I've had it for just over a year now but started using it end of March 2011.  So I've only been using it for 11 months.I've taken almost 5000 pictures with it and maybe about 50 1080p videos.The card is now dead.  I was able to recover my images before it died completely, but in my opinion, this card should have lasted a few years.  Especially considering I haven't even taken 5000 pictures!I guess you get what you pay for right?!"
20110318"
column1851: You Need Class 10 SD If You Shoot Full HD Video
column1852:
I bought a 8 GB SD card with a Speed Class of 10, because I use it to shoot Full HD video on my Sony XR150 camcorder. The larger the Class number, the greater the write speed of the SD card. Therefore this card can achieve a write speed of 10 Megabytes/second (or 80 Megabits/second).This is in accordance to recommendation by the Secure Digital Association (sdcard.org):Class 2 : H.264 video recording, MPEG-4, MPEG-2 video recordingClass 4: MEPG-2 (HDTV) video recording, DSC consecutive shootingClass 6: Mega-pixel DSC consecutive shooting, professional video cameraClass 10: Full HD video recording, HD still consecutive shootingWhen it comes to SD cards, other than SanDisk, Transcend is another brand that I trust."

column2025: Great quality for a low price! :)

The low price made me a little cautious but the good reviews definitely outweigh the bad, so I went with this one. Glad I did."
20110304"
column2029:
Good deal for a card this size, if you look around. 16gb formats to 15gb for file system. Everything does that.  I tested this card against several others I have. Here are my results.  First I copied 3.3gb of pictures and small video files to card (13,646 files!!!), took 6min 24sec. To delete same took, 5min 44sec. So, be ready for it to take time to copy, transfer, and delete, large amounts of data. This holds about THREE DVDS and then some when full!!! It will take time!!!  Very fast in my camera, took next to no time to delete several files of both types. Happy with that.  Test against 8gb class6, 8gb class 4 and 8gb USB stick for comparison.... Transfer of the same 729mb file, about a full CD, to device and from device to computer. A 3.2ghz single core from 2004ish. Remember this is just a one file test. Remember, multi-file transfers can take time for the Hard drive to find the next file, often there are stops. THIS CARD...from computer To card=58.66 sec, From card to computer, 43.30 sec. Delete was instant. Micro sdhc 8gb class 6. from comp. to card, 1:17.43, from card to comp. 43.21 sec. Delete was instant. 8gb Kingston USB stick. From comp to stick 1:16.74, From stick to comp. 43.65 sec. Delete was instant. Micro sdhc 8gb class 4. From comp to card 2:47.03, from card to comp. 51.15. sec. Delete took 6 sec. Starting the file transfer took 7 sec for recognition.  The time on all these started when I hit COPY on the requester, and ended at 100%, the class 4 stayed on 100% for 3-4 seconds after stopping. SLOW CARD!  You can see from this test, this card is faster on transfer from comp to card, but about the same on transfer from card to comp. So, it will depend on your needs. My 8gb class 6 is very fast in the same camera. So, if you need a 16gb card this is a tad faster, but a class 6 might just do the job and for a little cheaper.  For what this card does though, I am happy with it.Shipping was excellent, a good deal all-round. 4 days cross country from NY State.Thanks to Amazon!"
20110304"

At the same time, I bought an 8gb Eye-Fi card.  This product allows for a feature called 'Endless Memory' which it can do provided that you are near a network. And who knows, maybe I got a bad card."
20110302"
column2064: Works, but I wouldn't buy another Transcend Flash Memory Card - UPDATED
column2065:
While reading the reviews prior to ordering this card, a reviewer mentioned that the Transcend seemed to be physically over sized. I thought that the reviewer must be crazy, SD cards are a standard size. Well, I guess I too am crazy.I received the Transcend card this morning and after popping out the 8GB Kingston card that I had borrowed from my camera, I inserted the Transcend into my camcorder. The card just didn't feel right going into the camcorder, so I tried to pop it out. No go! Apparently when you press on it to pop it out, it releases, but it fits so tight in the slot, that the camcoder springs are not strong enough to pop it out. I had to get my finger nail on the edge of the card and pull it out of the slot.At that time, I remembered the review that mentioned that the Transcend was over sized. I compared the Transcend to my other SD cards, a Canon and a Kingston, and I could feel that the Transcend was a bit wider. Not happy.I figured since there is no reason why I would be popping the card in and out of the camcorder, I would keep it if it worked.So, for the last few hours I have formatted, recorded, copied and deleted, and the card seems to work fine with my camcorder.The fact that the card is over sized does not give me that warm fuzzy feeling that I would like to have. If Transcend can't size the card properly, what other problems are there, that are not so obvious?If I encounter any further problems, I'll update this review.I'll hang onto the card, but I will not purchase another Transcend item.UPDATE: February 10,2012.Well, I have to eat my words.I bought another Transcend memory card. This time a 32G card. Based the purchase on price and the fact that the ill fitting 16G card has worked flawlessly.I purchased the 32G card to be used with the same camcorder that the 16G card was being used with, thus I have been swapping the 2 cards.The new, 32G, card could be inserted and ejected from the camcorder, without binding, from day one, and after a few iterations of the 16G card being inserted and ejected, it no longer sticks.So, both cards work well and neither binds/sticks when being inserted and ejected."

I purchased this card for a DSLR which shoots video. I have several other cards that are 2gb, but extremely fast. But because I also shoot video, I needed much more space and ended up choosing this card. It is defenately not as fast as my other class 6 cards but for the most part it can keep up with 1080 resolution video. The reason I say for the most part is: it has caused my camera to stop recording on several occasions when the buffer fills up and the memory card cant keep up (generally under high contrasty and colorful scenes where more data needs to be written). But other than that, I have also filled up 8gb straight of video without problem.This card does what I needed it to, be able to allow me to shoot uninterupted HD video and for cheap.If I needed a fast card for shooting continous pictures of more than 15 frames or in raw mode I would look elsewhere."

column2118: Did not work in my HD Canon camcorder
column2119:
I bought this card in preparation for an upcoming vacation.  I'm glad I tested it prior to leaving as it did not work in my camera, or at leas not as advertised.  The camera simply displayed a message stating that I couldn't record in FXP mode (HD) with the current SD card (even though the technical details for the product state 'Perfect for vast amounts of HD video and high-resolution images'.  In fact I had to bump the resolution down 2 levels before the camcorder would allow me to record.  According to the documentation that came with my camcorder, it is capable of writing HD content to an SD card with a Class 4 speed rating.  So, while this card is advertised as a Class 10, I don't believe it actually is.  In addition to the problems using this card in my camcorder, the card also could not be read by the card reader in my PC with Windows 7.  I had to plug it into the card reader on my printer before my computer would recognize it.I returned the Transcend SD card and purchased a slightly more expensive 32GB Kensington SD card, and everything works as it should, in my camcorder, and in my PC."

column2154: Excellent low cost sd card for Canon T2i
column2155:

column2167:

Some new Blu-Ray players require an SD card to access extra features on line.  There is only one suggestion:  format your card before using it.  I formatted the card before transferring data and I haven't had any issues or problems at all.  Probably 8 GB will be overkill if you just want to use this as a storage device for extra features while playing your Blu-Ray discs. This card it's a bargain."
20110216"
column2170:
The Transcend 32GB Class 10 card is really a class 4.  I bought 2 of these and also 2 16GB class 6 cards.  The class six cards write at 12MB/sec while the class 10 cards write at about 5MB/sec.  Go figure?  If you look at the speed test reviews for the 32GB cards, they are for the 16GB version.  I would send the 32GB cards back but I'm too lazy.  On here now to buy some more 16GB cards.So...  I highly recommend the 16GB version of the cards (class 6) for > 10MB/sec write speeds.  The 32GB version of the card (class 10) isn't what it's made out to be.  It's slow.  STILL A GOOD VALUE, but much slower than their 16GB class 6 card."

column2188:
I bought this memory to use in my brand new Canon T2i (Rebel 550D) DSLR camera.  The Transcend Class10 memory truly lives up to its expectations. I have another Class 6 memory as well. While my old Class 6 memory will periodically stop recording in order to flush out the buffer, the new Class 10 memory is a blessing. I can definitely see a significant performance improvement using the new Class 10 memory, especially when recording full HD movie @30fps (frames per second) as well as taking large-sized fine quality (JPG) pictures @ the rated 3.7 fps.  Taking rapid-fire pictures using the Class 10 memory is an experience by itself (it feels like having a mini-machine gun in your hand, one can certainly co-relate the rapid clicking:-)). Never once, it had stopped during recording movie and pictures. It is blazing fast.As far as the rated capacity of 16GB, it truly is 16GB. As Canon T2i instruction manual clearly states, the memory must be formatted in the camera (instead of in the computer) to exploit the true capacity.Overall, I am very happy w/ the speed, capacity, quality, as well as the price of this memory."

column2232: Great card when it works - Transcend loses points for CS
column2233:
I had 2 of these cards.  One of them failed on my during my trip to Yosemite.  I almost always have a spare with me, but I didn't bring one with me this trip.  I was able to recover a few photos, and still had my iPhone as a backup, so nothing to cry over.My biggest gripe is when I sent my card back to Transcend for a replacement, it seems the Postal Service snatched my card!  I didn't get insurance or certify it (big mistake on my part I realize).  Lots of information I could post here, but the short story: I called Transcend and although the guy I talked to believed my story, there was nothing he could do without the physical media in his possession.  He offered me a bad discount of like 10% which is still more expensive than Amazon's price.  I'm not broke, and I don't really care that I had to spend $50 to buy another one.  (Yes, I STILL purchased ANOTHER Transcend 16GB card after this).  I am just a little disappointed at Transcend's customer service.I realize my experience probably isn't typical.  Failures happen and unloading your media off your card is important in case of failure.  I'm very happy I didn't really lose any data, but I'm disappointed with how Transcend handled the situation and really mad at the USPS for stealing my failed memory card.I give the card 4 stars, minus a star for one failing, minus another star for sub-par CS.  If this memory card doesn't fail on me after a while, I will give it another star or two, but Transcend must win me back first."

column2280: Fast, reliable, large capacity, good value overall
column2281:
Giving the insignificant price difference between a Transcend Class 6 vs. a Class 10 at the time of purchase I decided to splurge and pay the extra 2 dollars even though the little camcorder I'm using the card with claims that a Class 6 should be good enough for it.I ordered this item for 2 reasons:- At less than one dollar per GB, it's not a bad deal at all at the time I'm writing this but be aware that SDHC prices are in a free fall.- Transcend appears to make reliable SDHC cards and I've been happy with a previous Transcend SDHC (class 2) card purchase.FEATURES AND USABILITYThe included SDHC card, is sufficiently large to hold a large collections of pictures for a digital photo frame but this one is built for speed. 'Class 10' guarantees transfer speeds of at least 80 Mbit/s - or 10 Megabytes per second - which is about 66x in CD-ROM speed rating equivalent. This is not the highest class rating for SD cards but it's fast enough for most digital camcorders. In fact, most (like mine) are quite happy with the lower speed 'Class 6'. On a mostly still frame camera that accepts SDHC this should be a speed monster.It's worth noting that the card came formatted as FAT32. This is what most cameras would like to see but some Microsoft operating systems may not allow you to reformat and some older cameras may not be able to recognize anything over 4GB. My Windows 7 laptop could read the card through an included USB adapter. As for formatting it, there are public domain formatting utilities out there that would allow you to do it under XP, Vista or Windows 7 if your camera has trouble reformatting it.PACKAGING, CONTENTS AND WARRANTYIt was not easy to take the card and the adapter out of the near-bullet-proof plastic enclosure but a pair of powerful scissors did the job, eventually but not without cutting some of the included paperwork.Besides the card, there is a very generic, credit-card size 'manual' that comes with the usual warnings - don't touch the connectors, don't bend the card and so on.The lifetime warranty statement on the card (whose lifetime?) will have Transcend replace or repair your item if you still have your receipt and you don't do anything from a long list of activities and nothing  that's on a long list of possible happenings happens to the card (don't chew on it). In other words, it's meaningless.Finally, there's a card inside the package that promises 'free software' in the form of a 'photo recovery' tool from Transcend's site. It would install on the card itself if you go to the site with the card plugged in and have it download directly into the card. If it installs successfully, you should be able to recover some deleted photos and even photos lost because the card was formatted by mistake. I chose not to download the tool because I'd have no use for it but it's good that it's there.MY RATINGI like this card for its price, the card's relatively large capacity (32GB are also available) and for its speed. I do not appreciate the largely meaningless 'lifetime warranty' claims used to market the product but I don't care much about warranties on items for which the cost of shipping them to the vendor may come close or exceed the cost of buying a new one.Since the product does very much what I expect it to do, a 4-star rating - means 'I like it' - is fair."

column2286: Dependable Mass Storage for HD video shooting

This is the second Transcend 32GB Class 10 SDHC memory chip I have purchased. Both of them are for my GoPro HD Hero video camera and perform as expected. I went with Class 10 since there is little difference in pricing these days between this chip and the lower class versions. By the time I received this item the price had dropped another few bucks to below fifty dollars so if you are in no hurry put this item in your Wish List and you can easily monitor any price changes.I don't really care that much about transfer speeds when moving the video clips to the computer but wanted the Class 10 speed to make sure that the GoPro HD camera would not encounter any problems saving the files while recording. Because this 32GB size is getting very popular be sure that the equipment you intend to use it in is capable of handling 32GB of memory. A number of older digital cameras and other equipment that uses SDHC chips may have a 16GB limitation due to older firmware. Check with your tech support for that equipment's compatibility with this chip if you have doubts before ordering."

I would highly recommend this card and bought it because I have had consistently good results with Transcend cards and this card isn't any different."
20110121"
column2442: The best for professionals, with a price to go with it.
column2443:
To be perfectly honest, I would never have bought this prior to using it on a review loan from Transcend. I own many Transcend cards in multiple formats and sizes (mostly 32gb) and all perform beautifully; about one bad image per seven thousand: one SDHC for my Sony NEX-3; which shouldn't be underestimated as a profesional level camera, one CF and one SDHC card for my Canon 1Ds III; full frame and BIG for when I'm doing a fancy shoot that doesn't require too much mobility, one SDHC for a portable boot disk (should I not have my laptop and need my workspace on a computer), and one SDHC used with a USB reader as a flash drive (with a few other 8gb, 4gb, and 2gb cards). I got this card as a review unit from Transcend before they released it, and recently bought one myself at a discount from them only for when I go on long trips without my computer. I'm a freelance professional photographer, so in the usual day I'll be doing anything from a product shoot to college sports to a fashion show. Basically, all the small and medium businesses that can't payroll a full time photographer hire ones like me, usually on a regular basis. So I certainly keep myself busy and can rack up thousands of pictures in a day. Before I continue with the full review, I will mention that I used this primarily with my NEX-3, and for about an hour underwater SCUBA in my girlfriend's Panasonic Lumix DMC-TS2. My Canon 1Ds III doesn't support SDXC (sadly).Capacity: Massive! PRO.This card is massive beyond all others. 64gb is 4000 14MP RAW pictures. That's absolutely top of the line capacity. 4000 pictures is even above and beyond what I use in three or four large shoots. Usually I use JPEG, which is about a third to a fifth the size of a RAW image. On my NEX-3, it reported 10,250 14MP Fine JPEG pictures, double that (20,500) in 7.1MP Fine JPEG, and double THAT (41,000) in 3.5MP Fine JPEG. All of these are truly ridiculous. But that was for a full APS-C sensor camera at highest possible quality. When I put it in the DMC-TS2 for the first time, I thought it couldn't read the card and freaked, since the 'pictures left' indicator just kept flashing. I put it back into the NEX-3 and it was fine. So I figured I'd take a couple shots with the TS2 with the card in and see what happened. Lo and behold, it saved the pictures just fine. I put it into full high speed mode with a specially rigged remote to just hold the shutter button down, and came back about 20 minutes later to see if it showed a number. Eventually it hit 9,999 after it took 2,568 pictures. So this is a card that owns the market on capacity for SD cards.Speed: Not so fast, CON.This card starts to fall down when it comes to speed. It gets the Class 10 speeds just fine, but not much more than that. For those that don't know, Class 10 means that no matter what happens to the card short of being completely physically destroyed, it will have at least 10 Megabytes per second sustained write speed. I maxed out the card at burst speeds of around 15MBps, but that's it. It will handle HD video perfectly fine, but it won't write fast enough to use the magical 7fps continuous speed mode on my NEX-3 to the full advantage. It went for 20 JPEG shots at 7fps before slowing down to 2.3fps. It went for only 9 RAW shots at 7fps before going down to 2fps. This is both fault on the only medium sized image buffer, but mostly on the card. My Sandisk Extreme III card can keep up at around 5.5fps on RAW or JPEG continuous speed mode. This isn't a card to buy for the highest speeds, for that get a Sandisk Extreme card. I, II, or III doesn't matter, all are more than acceptable.Reliability: Among the best, PRO.This is never a big problem on any big brand memory such as Lexar, Sandisk, Patriot, Kingston, or Transcend. As far as I'm concerned, as long as it's less than one bad image in a thousand I'm fine with the card. I've never ever had a bad image on a Sandisk card, but I haven't used them enough to really tell. I've used them for ~10,000 shots, and none were bad. On Lexar, Toshiba, PNY, A-Data, and Kingston (who's SD cards are all the same) I get about one bad image per two thousand. So not too bad. Patriot does a little better, with one per three thousand. And finally Transcend, which gets one bad per 7000. So image corruption is never something to really worry about, and it's usually the camera that writes bad, not the card. On older or off brand point and shoots I get about one bad per hundred shots.Value: Absolute worst, CON.Definitely the worst point on this card. Before another story, I'll spare you: don't buy this card unless you really, really need to or really, really want to. I cringe every time I think about how much I spent on this card. I bought it for use on a week long European backpacking trip with my girlfriend, and neither of us brought our computers, so I needed the card capacity because of that, and I have to say that it served me well for the trip. Did I need it at all? No. Would I have been smarter and better off using a couple 32gb cards? Absolutely. But the peace of mind that came with knowing I couldn't fill it was nice. I did in fact send it back afterwards and bought another 32gb card and a battery each for my 1Ds III and NEX-3. Much better purchase for the money.Compatibility: Not too bad, but not good either. CON.SDXC didn't exist a couple of years ago, so unless your camera is fairly new it probably won't support this card. Go to the manufacturer's site and check the product info to be double and triple sure that it works with your camera. No real experience story here, it worked with both cameras I used it with and didn't work with a camera that it wasn't designed to work with.All in all, don't bother. You'd absolutely be better off buying two 32gb Class 10 cards and an extra battery, or one 32gb card and two extra batteries, etc, than buying this card. I can't see a true purpose for this card other than for size queens or sports photographers; but they're using CF cards. I rated this as it stands as a product, but there is virtually no marketable use for this other than maybe for expandable computer storage, in which case a 1TB portable hard drive is still cheaper. Heck, a 128GB SSD is cheaper than this!"

column2469: Only 5 pics in continuous mode before buffer fills

I'm not sure if this is the camera or the card so I won't unfairly ding the product but you should know that I have a Canon T2i and in the highest resolution setting under any of the manual modes (AV, TV, M) the camera will snap 5 pictures (in continuous mode) before the buffer fills up and you have to wait a few seconds to snap again. I'm a little dissapointed because my Canon Rebel Xsi has about half the resolution and when using a only class 6 card I get the same behavior. I was hoping that I would get 8 or more pics in continuous mode using this class 10 card and newer camera but alas I don't. For mere mortals this will be completely acceptable. But it makes me wonder if the money's worth it to move to class 10 when I get the same performance from a name brand class 6. So again, I don't know if this is the camera or the card, but if you were planning on shooting 5+ pics in continuous mode in high res without filling up the buffer, you won't - 5 is your limit. Fortunately I can live with that. Was just hoping for something more impressive."

I am using this sdhc card in the card reader slot of my laptop to backup and mirror certain data. The max write speed I was getting so far was 8.9 MB/s (the avarage is around 8.6 MB/s). This is of course for larger (>100MB) files and the data on the card is not fragmented yet. According to wikipedia ('The Class number represents a multiple of 8 Mb/s (1 MB/s), and meets the least sustained write speeds for a card in a fragmented state.') this card does not meet the requirements to be labeled class 10.Almost 1.5 MB/s slower than supposed to be means 15% less data per time frame.On the other hand one should consider at the time when I bought it it was the cheapest 32 GB class 10 SDHC card I could find plus it is noticeably faster than a class 6 card."

column2598: DO NOT BUY IF YOU WILL USE IT FOR VIDEO ON CANON DSLR
column2599:
I bought this for my Canon 60D because I plan on doing a lot of video stuff with it.  Basically, the card is too slow.  It is not a real class 10.  A class 10 means its MINIMUM write speed is 10 MB/s (megaBYTE not megabit).  The 60D records video at about 5-7 MB/s and during recording, it will tell me that the card is too slow and it has to buffer to catch up.  There have been multiple times in which it has automatically stopped recording because it was too slow.  Since the Canon T2i also uses SD, I suspect it will do the same thing.  I got a class 6 sandisk SDHC card and it works perfectly, not a single problem.  For pictures however, this card is fine, but it is not a class 10."

column2682: Does NOT work with Canon HFS100 but does with GoPro Hero HD
column2683:
If you're buying this 32gb class 10 chip to operate in a Canon HFS100 solid state camcorder, forget it unless you want to record at XP+ (12mbps) or lower. The two higher quality bitrates MXP (24mbps) and FXP (17mbps) will not record. Very disappointing.Also, when you select Memory Card Info from the menu, it does not recognize the card as Class 10. It says it's 32gb and displays all the other info, but not its class speed. The manual clearly states the HFS100 will record on Class 4 'or higher' SDHC cards. Except in the case of Transcend, it won't work. I really wanted to use this for long runs in my HFS100. The camera is clearly capable of handling 32GB cards, just not Transcend Class 10 32GB cards. According to Canon, there are no firmware updates announced for this camera. Bummer.Fortunately, the card seems to work fine in the little GoPro Hero HD camcorder, so I guess that's where it will reside.If you go to the Transcend website, they don't even list this part number. I'm sticking with better name brands for my cards."

column2742: Cheap and Fast memory.  No problem so far.
column2743:
Works great with Canon 60D.  Read speed 16MB/s.  Write speed 10+MB/s.  1080p video recording was no problem while no-name class 4 card choked in this mode.  To be fair,  my Kingston class 4 is able to do HD recording with no issue.I was hesitating before ordering due to the negative reviews.  I will wait to say anything about the longevity of this card.If this card seems to be slow to you,  double check the method used to calculate read/write speed.  I have one card reader that tops out at 5MB/s so every card performs like a class 2 in it.To reduce the chance of memory card corruption,  here are the DOs and DONTs1. Format the card in the device that you intend to use it in.2. Format the card every time after you copy the content off.3. Don't manually delete images one-by-one unless you absolutely have to.  You are fragmenting the future data and increasing the chance of corruption.4. Keep the battery charged and avoid running the device with little juice left."

column2766: It does the job very well for my application
column2767:
I've seen most all of the reviews here for this item's rating on read/write/transfer speed in cameras.  That's all well and fine, but my application is a GPS, a DeLorme PN-40 to be exact.  I purchased this card to keep all my TOPO9 maps so I won't have to load and unload whenever I go to different places to geocache.  Note, if you have a PN-40 and want to load the entire TOPO9 series, you WILL need a 32GB card.  Keep in mind now that the formatted size is 30.2GB, but yes, you will have a lot of space left over for POIs, too.Let's talk speed.  I also have a Garmin GPS, and map update downloading takes about an hour or so for roughly 1GB transferred and configured mapping to internal memory.  I inserted this particular card into my laptop, formatted it to FAT32, installed to my DeLorme GPS, fired up, and the card was immediately recognized.  I began to install the TOPO9 maps through my laptop (lower 48 only) and watched the process.  Two hours went by and only the first disc of four had been loaded.  Upon looking at what had taken place, I saw that over 4GB had been written in two hours.  A quick calculation told me that was about twice the speed as the Garmin download.  In the end, close to 22GB had been written in about eight hours.  Not bad at all in my book.  There was right at 8GB of space left over for POIs and waypoints - far more than I'll use, I'm sure.As for boot up time, it now takes the GPS about another 12 seconds to boot up and begin looking for satellites, than it did with no card in the slot.  Again, not bad at all.I bought mine at a very competitive price, but I see the price changes constantly.  If knowledge serves me correctly, this card, as all memory, is a commodity item, so the price will fluctuate.  When I bought mine, the price had changed three times in one day.  I got mine in the middle of the range.  Keep watching it because the price will change because it's the nature of the beast.I can't fairly compare it to the others at twice or three times the price, but I can say I am very pleased with the performance.  I have not tried this card in a camera, so I cannot rate it one way or the other in that application.  For the money, this card does the trick in a GPS."
20101227"
column2770:

20101227"
column2772: Good Flash Card for SSD HD Camcorders!
column2773:
I did the research on flash memory cards from several of the larger companies and read reviews on camcorders.  The negativity that people express with 'speed' is due to their own fault of not checking all the specs on camcorders.  As it stands, Class 10 memory cards are the fastest out there.  They are designed specifically for video.  A Class 4 or 6 works fine for digitial photos but not video due to the frames per second that can be written to the card.  The 'read' also allows for quick playback without any shuttering in the video transfer from the memory card to the TV!  A new format will be launched with Sony and a few others to 'standardize' the industry so all SSD will work interchangably (so I presume).  Regardless, when you read reviews on camcorders being slow, take heed that they are likely complaining about the flash memory card being anything less than a Class 10!  By the way, a 1280x720p video lasting about 8 minutes consumes 728MB of the memory card.  Might want to have a few of these if you are shooting in 1080p (i = interlaced) but regular video in non-HD format will use significantly less memory.  Nonetheless, I find that 720p is quite sufficent for almost all video playback needs unless you are a professional."
20101226"
column2776:
Not sure if anybody else has experienced this. I recently bought two of these cards and without testing them at home took them on a road trip. I normally use a Mac for all photography related work but on the trip had only access to a PC. I backed up the cards to the PC on the road. Upon returning home, I stuck the cards and reader into a Mac to download the pictures. One card read briefly and then Mac started giving me the 'You should eject the media properly etc. etc.' The other did not even show up. Perplexed, I tried the cards on a PC and lo and behold they were readable. Took them to a second PC, and while one read fine, the other one now showed a card on which the files were corrupted. Brought the good one back to the Mac and again the computer failed to recognize the media. It seems like once inserted into a Mac these cards behaved real strange and subsequently became unusable.Other non Transcend media read fine in the SDHC reader so it was not a problem with the reader.I have to sadly dispose of these cards as they are of no use to me.My backups performed on the road saved the day for me. My first experience with Transcend is a strange  one. I will look elsewhere.Also, the cards that arrived were Class 10 however, the face label was not black/grey but orange/yellow."
