column2778: Why does the price keep going up?
column2779:
Dear Amazon,Why do you insist on raising the price, AFTER I have put this in my wish list or cart?  This card was $49 when I saved it to buy later, and now when I come back to buy it you have raised it to $60???  I find this to be dirty pool.  I will not be buying from you, have a good day."
20101226"
column2782:
I paid around $50-$55 for this huge SD, 32gb. The price is even better if you think that this is a Class 10 SD, which means 10mb/s of writing speed. I use this SD with a Camcorder that has a very high bitrate, since it is a 60 fps @ Full HD, so I needed a fast SD in order to write on it without getting errors. It worked fine so far, and I'm happy with it, I got a nicely working 32 gb card without raping my wallet on a Sandisk Extreme, faster for sure but probably a speed I don't need for my application."
20101226"
column2785:
I purchased this card after reading/watching reviews on amazon.com, I could not say anything technically about this card but this is perfect card with great speed for my Canon rebel T1i DSLR camera for both snaps & HD video."
20101224"
column2788:
At the time I am writing this review, the Transcend 8gb class 10 SDHC card is priced at an incredible value.  That is the primary reason why I am giving this SDHC card a high rating.  Frankly, as far as class 10 memory goes, this is a pretty slow card, and I think it performs more like a class 4 in terms of write speed.  However, for most people, this card is really fast enough.  It can copy images to a computer very quickly, and most people don't even have a camera with shooting speeds that are limited by the memory card.  If you own a dSLR, and speed is your concern, check out SanDisk class 10.  If getting reasonable speeds at a bargain price is your concern, look no further and buy this card.I compared the following four SD memory cards:1) Kingston 2 GB SD Flash Memory Card 2-Pack SD/2GB-2P2) Lexar SDHC 4 GB Class 6 Flash Memory Card 100x Jewel Case Envelope Bulk LSD4GBBE1003) Transcend 8GB Class 10 SDHC Card (TS8GSDHC10)4) Sandisk 8GB Extreme SDHC Card-Class 10 (SDSDX3-008G-A31)I compared the photo shooting speeds and the speeds to copy pictures onto a computer for the four different SD cards. I inserted the SD card into my Canon T1i dSRL, formatted the SD card, and shot in RAW+jpeg (which in this case was two files, 19.5mb and 4.7mb respectively). I timed how long it took to shoot 20 pictures, and then I timed how long it took to move those 40 files onto my computer. The T1i buffer filled up after 4.5 shots, so the remaining shots all depended on the write speed of the memory card. I didn't see too much difference in the time it took to copy the files to my computer, but there was a noticeable difference in the shooting speeds. The SanDisk class 10 SDHC card was clearly the fastest, but it was also the most expensive.Shooting Speed1) SanDisk 8gb class 10 SDHC (24 sec)2) Kingston 2gb SD (38 sec)3) Lexar 4gb class 6 SDHC (39 sec)4) Transcend 8gb class 10 SDHC (45 sec)Copy to Computer Speed1) SanDisk 8gb class 10 SDHC (34 sec)2) Kingston 2gb SD (34 sec)3) Lexar 4gb class 6 SDHC (38 sec)4) Transcend 8gb class 10 SDHC (40 sec)Besides the speed differences, I have not noticed any other difference between these four memory cards. They are all compatible with everything I have (except for a few things that do not take SDHC cards). I have never lost anything on an SD card, and none of my cards have ever broken or failed. However, I do take very good care of them, and I always format the cards after copying pictures onto my computer. Depending on your needs, you may not need 8gb, or you may not need very fast write speeds. If speed matters to you, go with SanDisk...it is the fastest. Otherwise, consider a cheaper alternative."
20101224"
column2791:
Seems all the negative reviews are coming from folks with fancy high speed cameras.  This card works fine for my Panasonic camcorder."
20101224"
column2794:
Just got a new Canon 60D and bought this as my memory card. Does everything I need it to do. I don't shoot super fast, so this does all I need. A great value for the price!"
20101224"
column2797:
I suggest you look at the video and written review 'Stephen' dated April 11, 2010; that's what I did.  I purchased this for use in my flash based HD camcorder and it works great!  No issues, no lag, formatted it in the camcorder in seconds.  For the price and speed, this can't be beat.  I will be buying another one of these."
20101224"
column2800:
Hola,bueno no esperen una opinion concreta recien lo tengo 1 mes,pero hasta ahora no me ha fallado, la velocidad de lectura ayuda para grabar en full HD."
20101222"
column2803:
Works well and well built. Used it in my new Sony tablet without problems. I have always liked SD memory cards and have had no problems. Would recommend it."
20101222"
column2806:
My new camera came with a minimal memory card so I purchased this one. Based on the size of the card,and the fact that I delete all the images everytime they are down-loaded, it's probably the only card I'll ever need.I take a lot of photos, especially on vacation and video too- so this is the perfect size for someone who can't afford to run out of space on a trip or because the video ate up all the memory."
20101221"
column2808: This works flawlessly with Canon T2i
column2809:
I used it with Canon T2i to record HD video without hiccup. It is the best value I could find."
20101221"
column2812:
I've been using Transcend SD cards for 3 years now in my digital cameras.  I've taken some 15,000 shots and never lost an image with these cards.  The write speed does not slow me down.  I can shoot sub-second bursts without any delay.  I bought mine with a bundled SD-to-USB card reader that I've used to read the digital images into my computer, and that works great too.  So why spend more for SD cards from other vendors?  Beats me.-- Jim"
20101221"
column2815:
I needed a SD card in a hurry and I was not dissapointed in the delivery time.I got it fast and the price was great."
20101221"
column2818:
I purchased 2 Transcend 16GB class 10 SDHC cards for use in my Nikon D7000. So far they have worked extremely well. I can't see why anyone would spend a higher price for another brand."
20101220"
column2821:
I use this card with my netbook to expand its storage.  It is nicer than a USB stick becuase it does not stick out of my computer.  I also plug it into my desktop to sync data, and it is quite fast.  None of my computers have any trouble recognizing and using it (Windows XP, Windows 7, Debian Lenny), so I am quite happy.  The little case it comes with is nice too when I just need my data, not my whole computer."
20101220"
column2824:
My computer has trouble recognizing and reading this card. The problem has to be with the card, because my computer doesn't have any problems recognizing and reading my other SDHC cards made by other manufacturers. I wouldn't buy this again regardless of the price."
20101220"
column2827:
Reliable card. I bought two for my camera nikon D7000 and write speed is very good for both photos and video. I have no complaints and the price is much lower than others of equal performance."
20101220"
column2830:
There isn't a whole lot that you can say about a flash card. It works great with the video camera. It's fast and easy to use. Great card for the price!"
20101220"
column2833:
I have use Transcend SCHD class 6 cards. This class 10 is great. I've purchased 4/ 32gb class 10 for video recording and I'll be purchasing more in the future. Great card."
20101220"
column2835: HERES THE ACTUAL BREAK DOWN OF THIS CARD (FOR CANON T2I USERS)
column2836:
I recently Purchased this card, as well as a Canon Rebel T2i, The first time i put it in i had got great results with this, i took pics and video at the highest quality, but what i noticed what started to happen is in movie mode, after the 7th video i tried to rec, it would 'automatically stop recording' due to the buffer, What i had to do was save everything on the card to my hard drive and freshly Format The card in the camera, With this card you have to pick and choose what you want to do and be dedicated to it, meaning If You have Pictures and Video on this card, The Buffer will always max out!I was able to record the max 4gb per Recording 4 times on the rebel t2i with this card with the buffer only showing at 1 bar , but i had to change the card to another one to take Pictures, its a slight hassel but trust me regardless of the fact with this card you can only have 1 type of media on it at a time, Either Pictures, Or Video"
20101219"
column2838: Great card for price and direct from Amazon.
column2839:
This is a great card for the price. It is fast and performs well. In addition, ordering directly from Amazon, selecting 'Package Type: Amazon Frustration-Free,' you can save on shipping too with free standard shipping. Plus a lot fewer hassles with Amazon if you need to return the product for any reason. Note, you will not receive the manufacturer's packaging with this selection, but a simple clam shell case only. I think a lot of the customers who have given this card a bad rating have seemed to actually have problems because the card is incompatible with older devices, not the brand that they bought. Since SDHC is a new SD card format which is able to handle larger memory--SD cards were only able to hold 2GB--they had to create a new format. Check with your device's specifications before ordering these new format cards."
20101219"
column2841: Good alternative to the big name brands
column2842:
This memory card is just as functional as the big name brand cards. I was a little leery about buying a card that wasn't mentioned in the manual for the camera, but am glad I did. I saved about 40-50 dollars depending on where I looked for the card in this size.The amount of pictures the card will hold is of course dependent on the megapixels you set the camera on, the lower the megapixel setting on your pictures the more you can take. With the size of this card any novice user will have more than enough room for photos/videos. The item arrived in perfect condition from Amazon and actually arrived a day early which was awesome.The speed on the card is great, those who take alot of pictures will benefit more from this information than someone who only takes a few pictures. Basically the faster the speed of the card, the faster it saves the picture to the card allowing you to take the next picture. Like I said unless you take rapid succession photos this will mean nothing to you. The higher the megapixel of the picture the longer it would take to save due to the amount of detail in the photo. This card exceeded my expectations on all fronts. I recommend it to anyone."
20101219"
column2845:
I wanted a decent amount of memory so I would never have to stop an wonder, do I have enough space? Also speed was important. This is my second Transcend product, I also have a 64GB compact flash card for my Canon 7D and it has worked wonderfully and spped has never presented an issue.So far my experience with Transcend memory has been all positive"
20101218"
column2848:
The Transcend 8GB Class 10 SDHC card is a freat value.The card is perfoming flawlessly and the price was amazing."
20101218"
column2851:
This card has zero lag time for me. Ultra fast and at a great price. I have a 60d and take 1080p video with it no problem. The card can also handle the 5.3 fps continuous burst mode!"
20101217"
column2854:
I'm not sure this Card is truly a Class 10 card. But, it's sufficiently fast enough for my Canon T2i. My litmus test is whether it can handle recording 1080p video on the camera. For this, it's worked flawlessly. The video is smooth, with no frame loss, and no choppiness. So whether it's truly Class 10 or not, I don't care. It meets my needs. Good card, the brand has a good reputation, and I hope it continues being reliable for me."
20101217"
column2856: Good card, use it in my Canon T2i
column2857:
Both stills and video look great, very fast card.  Price was pretty good though I have noticed it go down since I bought it."
20101216"
column2859: I should have read the description more carefully
column2860:
I originally bought this for my Cannon Vixia HF200.  I didn't pay attention to the write speed of the memory card.  It doesn't write fast enough to get the full HD potential of my camcorder.  This card is still an exceptional value (hence the 5 star rating) and it was my fault for not verifying the write speed required by my camcorder.  I might just use this card for my point and shoot digital camera so that I only have to download pictures once every 3 years.  16GB can hold a lot of 7 mega-pixel pictures."
20101216"
column2862: SDHC chip works but is very slow. Not the 10 its rated at.
column2863:
The Memory chip seems to be working but I paid for a class 10 to be sure it will work well with a video camera I have ordered ( should arrive tommorrow) so I cant say if the slow speed of this chip will be a problem yet, I was testing other chips for speed when this arrived in the mail and tested it as soon as I got it. It tested at 7.7 for writing and only 3.7 for reading. Thats comparable to a Toshiba rated at only a class 2 but tested at 3.6 for reading and writting at 7.7. Dont pay extra for this chip because of its speed rating. It tests no better than chips rated much lower. The price was not bad and delivery, by Amazon was very fast, but dissapointed in the performance."
20101216"
column2866:
If you thought that a card that exceeds your device's minimum specs (e.g. Class 4 or 6) you would be wrong.  My Canon Vixia HF10, now 2 years old, doesn't support the use of Class 10 cards for recording high bitrate HD video, according to their support web site. Check on this for your device before ordering.  My two star rating is from misleading advertising on this product. There should be a disclaimer to this effect somewhere fairly prominent.  This card may work fine for devices that support it, however."
20101216"
column2869:
I bought this card as an upgrade for my Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ28.  I was previously using a class 6 8gb kingston card, which I was happy with, however the Transcend card is at least twice as fast as I always had at least a 1 second lag for the storage of the pictures, this one is *almost* instant in comparison.  The only place I did not see a difference with the speed of the card is during night shots that required 1 or more seconds with the shutter open, however I think my camera controls this function as for instance if I took a 5 second capture, then the recording time was also 5 seconds.  I have taken a couple hundred pictures and had no problems with the card whatsoever. I'm very happy with this brand and purchase."
20101215"
column2871: Perfect Card to take HD Video using Canon Rebel T2i
column2872:
It works really well on my Canon Rebel T2i DSLR when taking HD Video at 30 fps. I have been using Transcend 4GB SD Card that I bought along with the Camera, however I needed a card with a larger space to record more HD Video. I had tried to reuse different brand of SD card (PQI Class 6) from my old camera to take the video, but the camera would stop recording it within 10 secs due to the lack of speed. So I ended up ordering this Transcend 16GB SD card which is cheaper than other name brand company. I am very happy that I mad the right decision."
20101215"
column2875:
I got this card a couple days before a trip to Utah National Parks and Las Vegas.  All went well the first few days, and fortunately I downloaded the pictures to my laptop every evening.  One evening in Vegas, I was bustling around, grabbing photos of so many wonderful sights - the fountains, lights, etc.  Then suddenly, as others had said happened to them, the camera was unable to access the card.  I immediately shut off the camera and changed cards.  After being unsuccessful in getting any software to access the pictures, I sent the card to Transcend Tech Support, and they said they will try to recover the pictures, and send them to me on a replacement card.  At this point, we are still waiting.I also bought a PNY 8 GB card, and another Transcend 8 GB class 6 card.  Both of those are still working fine. For future purchases, I might just spend a bit more and get the Sandisk card, depending on how it goes with the cards I have."
20101215"
column2878:
I have no problem taking photos and video with this memory card.  32GB is also huge, as I can take about 5,500 pictures at 14.1MP size.  I had trouble using it to transfer files from my desktop to my laptop (both running Win7), as the desktop kept wanting to scan the card for errors, and it didn't transfer all my files to the card.  I reformatted the card, and that didn't help.  The error message it was giving me is more common with hard drives, saying the destination can't be found, the original folder doesn't exist, etc.  But I didn't have any problem at all with my laptop, so I think the problem is with my desktop.  I ended up using a thumb drive to transfer the files.  But as far as using it in my camera, no problem."
20101214"
column2880: Not reliable if reader or camera is not new enough
column2881:
The transfer speed is fast, but not quite reliable on older reader. The data crashed twice. Reformat the memory not improve the reliability"
20101214"
column2884:
GOT THIS IN 4DAYS PLUG THE CARD INTO CAMERA AND FORMAT IT TOOK A FEW SECONDS, HAS LOADS OF ROOM FOR PICTURES."
20101213"
column2887:
Alright, so perhaps I bought a faulty card, but I bought this along with a new camera.  I put the card in my camera and started taking pics...well it kept freezing up, and I'd get a fault display.  It wasn't saving some of the pictures as well.  I thought it was the camera, but when I put in my 16gb PNY Optima SD card, it worked great.  So, there's definitely some kind of design fault with this memory card.  I would definitely not recommend it to anyone!"
20101213"
column2889: Good speed for such a great price!
column2890:
Bought it during Thanksgiving week.It was so cheap that it's priced nearly the same as the lower Class ones.This is really a Class 10 SD card. R/W speed is amazing.I've used a few Transcend CF/SD cards and SSD drives over the year (around 5 years ago).They may not be as famous as other brands like Lexar or Sandisk, but they do offer great Solid-state storage devices at great price."
20101213"
column2892: So far, so good!  Very pleased with Transcend 16GB class 10
column2893:
This Transcend SDHC card has been excellent so far.  I've been using more and more Transcend memory cards because they appear to be closing the gap with higher end memory card manufacturers like SanDisk.  Many people have been using these cards for very long periods of time, and although I think there could be very slight differences in write speed between a class 10 SanDisk card and a class 10 Transcend card, I think that most people will not ever use these cards in a capacity to notice much of a difference (if any).  I also own a SanDisk Extreme card (class 10) and I don't notice a difference between the write speed of the SanDisk card and the Transcend card, even when shooting a lot of consecutive photos on my Canon T2i.  One instance that I have heard that it would be worth getting the SanDisk over the Transcend is if you shoot HD video in the full HD mode for extended periods of time, and even then, you would probably be fine with the Transcend class 10 cards for that purpose.As you will probably notice, more and more people are trusting Transcend for keeping their precious pictures safe from being corrupted or unreadable.  I expect that Transcend memory cards will continue closing what little gap there is between their memory cards and those of the top of the line competitors, but their prices will probably go up too (closer to those of the bigger name brands).  In my opinion, Transcend is now a name brand, and I don't even hesitate to buy their memory card products (CF and SDHC), particularly when I see that they cost 20-40% less than their SanDisk counterparts.  I can't knock SanDisk... they are proven, and I have a number of great memory cards manufactured by them, but I no longer find it necessary to pay a premium for their products now that Transcend makes such good and consistent memory cards."
20101213"
column2896:
Bought 4 of these for us in my Canon EOS 60D, for shooting video... Never had a single problem during an intense week-long feature documentary shoot!"
20101212"
column2898: A good value in memory cards
column2899:
Its a memory card, and it works. Yep, that's right, it stores binary data just fine. Using it in an Olympus E-5 camera and it does its job. Good value."
20101212"
column2902:
I was a little reluctant to purchase a memory card from Transcend, mainly because I was concerned about quality control and I typically purchase more well known cards.  Nonetheless, the price was right so I opted to pick up two of them for my point and shoot.  My concerns have been put to rest and I've run them through their paces without any trouble.Some might say that these cards are not quite up to par with a true class 10 card, but for my purposes, that hasn't mattered.  I've been able to capture full HD video with my Canon SX130IS and haven't experienced the slightest bit of trouble.  Image capture seems to be fast enough and the card doesn't keep me waiting.  No unexpected failures or other problems to report so far.  I can get just over 5000 12-megapixel images on one of these cards or about an hour and a half of HD video.  If you're working with HD video, the 32GB cards might be more suitable - but I've always been a fan of using more, smaller density cards than putting all my eggs in one basket with very large density cards.As an amateur photographer with occasional client projects, I probably would opt for a better known brand for some of my critical shoots...but for less critical applications and personal work, I now feel comfortable with using these cards.  Eventually, I'll probably get another 2-3 of these cards since I've been getting into HD video more and the space requirements for that are crazy!Overall, five stars for a good product at a great price!"
20101212"
column2905:
This card performs slower than my Class 4 cards.  Terrible!  To slow to record MXP HQ video on my camcorder.  Testing shows that this card performs half the speed of my other Class 4 Cards!!!DO NOT BUY!"
20101212"
column2907: Not as fast as the Sandisk Extreme
column2908:
Not recommended for shooting HD video. Used with the Canon 60D and kept stopping after a few seconds, eventually recorded more than a few minutes of continuous HD video."
20101212"
column2911:
I think I got 17MB/s write and 19MB/s read on 4MB block. However when I use it in my netbook it is kind of slow to write. There will be this lag before it gets it in there, but for the price can't really complain."
20101211"
column2913: Don't let the low price make you think it's an inferior card! NO WAY!!!!
column2914:
The Transcend 16GB Class 10 SDHC Card, is a very excellent card for the money. During these hard economic time's, it's nice to know that there are still good bargain's to be found. The Transcend 16GB Class 10 card is also an excellent, fast performing card. You get what you pay for plus some, without the high cost that Sandisk charges. Sandisk charges about $79.25 for their 16GB Class 10 Card. That's more than twice as much money than this very budget friendly Transcend card. Sandisk's card's will not give you a picture that's twice as crystal clear either. If anything their high priced card's will set your wallet back for more than twice the price. Most of these type of cards are mass produced over sea's, and they cost just a few pennies to make, now you get the picture.Do not hesitate to get this very fair priced card. With the extra money you save, you can use that extra money to buy other accessories for your camera. This card is for those of you, budget minded, on a very responsible budget. It's also for those hesitant to spend a ridiculous amount of money, for some big name, when clearly you don't have to. The only big I care about, is big saving, and some extra money left over at the end of the day. You will not be disappointed with this card if it's used under normal, or fast shooting situations. Do not feel that the costlier Sandisk card's will make you a more professional photographer, with a more professional card, nothing could be further from the truth. Now that I think about it, Transcend is also a very big name, and it get's the same job done, for far less money. Sandisk Extreme III 8GB class 10 card cost $79.95 Reg. $89.95. Sandisk class 6 8GB cards, cost about $26.00 that's about as much as this more superior, $26.00 Transcend class 10 16GB card. Sandisk is not even pretending, nor attempting to be perceived as fair priced, or competitively matching the competition's best offer. Sandisk appears to be branded for those making a six figure income, not yet affected by today's tough economic conditions."
20101211"
column2916: Dont Purchase for HD Video 24/30fps recording
column2917:
I would recommend this memory card for stills and stills only! I got out on several shoots and found myself running into Movie mode has stopped automatically because this class 10 card cant handle the 1920 x 1080 24fps shooting on a t2i. I just recently purchased the Sandisk Extreme 16g Class 10 card and havent had that issue at all! So again, if you have a tight budget and get this card, I recommend you use it for stills only! If you are recording video, get a more reliable card that might cost more money, but in the long run will work and be a little bit more reliable when it comes to shooting HD video! I will keep the Trancend 32g class 10 card, but will use it as a back up when I am transferring the files from my Sandisk to my computer, and then pop the Sandisk back in.Lauren"
20101210"
column2919: Extra capacity for my Panasonic video camera
column2920:
I was in the market for a full HD video camera and selected the Panasonic HDC-TM series based on various reviews.  This series came with 3 internal memory options (None, 8 Gb, and 16 Gb).  I found a deal on the 16 Gb version that cost the same as the camera without internal memory.  All cameras in this product line include a SDHC slot that will accommodate a card up to 32 Gb.  As these 32 Gb cards have dropped significantly in cost, I thought it was a good time to max out the memory in my camera.  This card offered the best speed and price combination of all that I looked at."
20101209"
column2923:
I currently shoot in Raw image format using a Canon.I can say that this memory card works fairly good. I mean fairly because my SD Extreme III 30MB/s is a faster memory card and performs better overall.That being said, this memory card is an excellent card for the price.It does have a little slower upload from flash memory to the actual memory card.But lets face it, for the price it certainly is worth buying. Plenty of storage space for the price.While it is a Class 10 it seems to work at about 8-10MB/s, again for the price I can't complain.Price: 10/10Performance: 6.5/10Upload time: 7/10Worth Buying: YES!Would I buy a second or third. YES!Should you buy it. YES!"
20101209"
column2926:
Please beware of other reviews with performance criticisms. SD card performance is dependent on the device interfacing with the card. My 16gig Class 10 rated differently on two of my laptops.Dell E1505 - (4 year old XP)-------- 3.6MByte/s Write and 13.0 ReadDell E6510 - (new Windows 7)-------- 15.4MByte/s Write and 17.8 ReadAs you can see the throughput is well above the Class 10 rating with a proper device. Tested with H2testw.exe."
20101209"
column2929:
I bought two of these for my Nikon D7000. I had previously been using 8GB Class 2 cards, and they just weren't cutting it for my 16MP camera. This card never lags, and is very quick. Highly recommended!"
20101209"
column2932:
After a few months intensive use the blue plastic casing came apart. I would advise against buying this product. I have had no such bad experiences with Kingston."
20101207"
column2934: For The Price, You Really Can't Ask For More.
column2935:
I was in need of a SD card for my Canon T2i, and wasn't sure which card to go with considering all the reviews coming from every which way. So I took a chance with this one against the Sandisk Extreme III. And I must say, so far I feel I made the right choice. Speed? Its nothing to really complain about. For the average user it has more than enough speed. Price? You won't find anything cheaper for a 16GB sd card.So all in all this card really paid off, because you can't beat that price tag for something that performs well for most people."
20101207"
column2938:
I like the product. It was delivered fast. The only thing I cannot understand is why when it is read the computers read it as a 15GB and not a 16GB. There is some problem with the computer reading it but that might just be the computers. Still is great for storage and portability of pictures and school work."
20101206"
column2940: Fast and works great with my Canon 60D
column2941:
Great memory card and amazing price. It's very fast and reliable. I've been using it for nearly a month now without any problems."
20101206"
column2943: Great Price for size and performance
column2944:
I got this for my father's new Canon Rebel T2i. He wanted something high-capacity and fast.This fit the bill. It was a lot cheaper to get one online, which was my biggest appeal.I also had a hard time finding any Class 10 cards elsewhere.This card is fast enough for him to record 1080p HD videos and keep up with his quick shooting of 18 Megapixels.Transfers of the files to his computer are also fast.I have the 8GB Class 6 version of this card I bought about a year ago and would recommend both."
20120407"
column2946: The frustration is not worth the savings!!!
column2947:
I bought this for my new DSLR camera hoping to save some money. I've had it for 5 months now and it is VERY hit and miss. It doesn't act like a class 10 most of the time. It feels more like a class 4. I try to record video and it automatically stops recording after 3-5 seconds. Every once in a while I'll get lucky and it'll record for longer. So unless you want to record 3-5 second clips, Do Not buy this card!!! I read all the reviews on this product before purchasing and saw most were ok, but don't be fooled. I'm writing this review to warn you about falling into the same pitfall I fell into by buying this card. Spend the extra 10 or 20 bucks to ensure you're camera isn't going to stop recording during the memorable moments you're trying to capture. You'll wish you spent more and bought a decent card WHEN it does. The only reason I gave it more than one star is that is performs ok most of the time if you're just shooting photos. Other times it'll take upwards of 5 seconds before it'll let you take another picture."
20120406"
column2949: Didn't perform well - distorted footage and glitches
column2950:
I ordered this card after checking out all the reviews. I used it right out of the box for a weekend event and pretty much used it up a total of 3 times with my canon t3i. I checked the footage on multiple computers from my hard drive and footage is displayed the same way. I used another card that same weekend and didn't have one issue with that card. column3018: Too Slow For Video - Poor Performance
column3019:
Although the price may seem right, the performance isn't.  The Transcend 32GB Class 10 automatically stopped recording on the first full day of shooting using the Canon EOS 60D (the camera was NOT overheating).  This is something an event shooter like myself cannot afford.  I have been reading the blogs and have found this issue a common one, particularly with cheaper SDHC cards like Patriot and Transcend and even possibly counterfeit Sandisk Extremes sold through shady vendors (always buy direct from Amazon or a trusted vendor like B&H).Why risk losing important footage that is your livelihood just to save $100 on one purchase?  I've asked myself this question and have come to the conclusion that I'm sticking with Canon recommended Sandisk Extreme Class 10 SDHC cards only.  I have an 8BG Sandisk Extreme Class 10 and have never had any issue.Bottom line:  You get what you pay for.  Cheap storage = cheap performance.  This Transcend 32GB Class 10 is going into my Zoom H4n as it's new home, hopefully it can handle that!"

I'll be honest:  I bought one of these just to try out the Class 10 speed, hoping picture-taking would be faster with a 'faster' card.  Well, it's not quite like that. I save almost a good 30 minutes on a full (!) card and can thus reload quicker.I use these cards for my Canon Rebel xS, Canon S90 and a new Canon SX2100.  You get more for your bang on this card than with a same-brand of just 4GB or 8GB.  However, all memory cards eventually fail and when this one fails, the photographer loses a lot of awesome photographs.  It's the risk one takes as a photographer.  However, if your camera pack doesn't allow for much room, then go with this one and save the extra space for an additional, fully-charged battery.I will be buying a few more of these in the near future. column3076:
Pros:The capacity meets the spec at 32 billion bytes.The sequential write speed meets the class 10 spec at 10 megabytes per second.It is compatible with SDHC devices.It carries a lifetime warranty.Cons:However, from my experience and from reading reviews, it appears that the performance of the 'Ultimate' cards are inconsistent. I was unlucky and received one without '20MB/s' printed on it. As one might guess, the performance changed with the labeling change. Unlike earlier cards that exceeded the class 10 requirements and advertised the fact, the current cards are just class 10, nothing more. It looks like a bait and switch to me.The average speed I am getting is:random read: 8815 KB/s  sequential read 16.1 MB/srandom write: 5530 KB/s  sequential write 9.8 MB/sClass 10 means that the sustained write speed should be at least 10MB/s. Mine just barely scrapes by on speed.Bottom line:Ignore the early reviews and expect nothing more than the minimum specs the manufacturer promises. It is still a good card, just not as good as the earlier units."

column3096: Transcend Vs. Sandisk on Panasonic LX5
column3097:
I will be writing this review for both SanDisk Extreme SDHC class 10 8gb and Transcend SDHC class 10 16gb.I bought SanDisk class 10 and Transcend class 10 for my new Panasonic LX5.  I got both card because no one really did a comparison with a compact camera and I was just going crazy trying to see if there is any big difference between the 2 cards.SanDisk Extreme package box indicated it's water proof, x-ray proof, shock proof, temperature proof. I am not ready to spend $50 to see if it really stand up to it's words.  And I don't think normal people would go through the extreme condition in taking pictures or videos.Cut the story short, I really want to see if there is any difference in writing performance between the 2 cards in a compact camera.  There is a continuous burst mode in LX5 and the manual indicated it is only limited by the condition of picture environment and performance of the SD card.  Within the mode there are 2 different settings:1) speed priority or 2) picture/quality priority.  The shutter speed is much faster with speed priority compare to picture priority.I first formatted both cards out of box then put each card in series of test(3 rounds each setting for each card) shooting at the same object under same lighting condition. The results:Speed Priority:SanDisk Class 10 8gb22-33 shots before camera stopped to allow the card to catch up with writing.Transcend Class 10 16gb22-24 shots before camera stopped to allow the card to catch up with writing.Picture prioritySanDisk Class 10 8gb34-46 shots before camera stoppedTranscend Class 10 16gb27-33 shots before camera stoppedIt seems that at a higher shutter speed, both cards performed very similar under the same shooting condition.  But at a  slower shutter speed the SanDisk definitely out perform Transcend.  I hope this little experiment satisfied anyone with curiosity like me.  Transcend definitely is a bargain with 16gb and almost half of the price compare to SanDisk.  But I am going to use SanDisk Extreme as my primary card and Transcend as backup or on a second camera to ensure i would not miss any shots."
20101112"

column3105: Great quality, but just a tad too slow for a Class 10.
column3106:
I'm currently using the 16GB in my Pentax K-x DSLR.Fast! Well, fast for the price! So far it's been reliable, offers great storage, and takes my pictures like a champ. Probably all you could ask for from a SDHC card of this caliber.Most people in the DSLR hobby tend to choose between a single 16GB, or two 8GB. I decided to go with the 16GB route, forfeiting the backup memory for convenience instead. I can't say I regret it at all.My only issue is that this card feels more like a Class 6 than a class 10. For the price, I cannot complain - It's still faster than most Class 6 cards, although not fast enough to compete with other high-end Class 10's. Maybe this should be qualified as a Class 8?Ah, well - Either way, if you're going for the price+performance ratio like I am, then this card is tough to beat. I will certainly buy more in the future."

I do regret, however, that I did not try a Class 6 as some reviewers have said would have been sufficient. But at least I know that no matter how much I upgrade my camera in the foreseeable future, this card will work fine."

column3115:
I use a Panasonic G2 and have been using kingston class 6 and class 4 cards.  Realised that it took a long time saving Raw files so after reading some of the reviews of this card, i decided to get one... And the performance is Great !  it really speeds up saving RAW or Jpeg+Raw and you actually can feel the difference..I decided to run some tests using my Win 7 x64 PC with a SD card reader..  Using a sw called CrystalDiskMark 3.0, I get the following results..Kingston 8 GB SDHC Class 4.  Sequential Write (50 MB ) = 5.9 Mb/SKingston 8 GB SDHC Class 6.  Sequential Write (50 MB ) = 6.9 Mb/STranscend 16 GB SDHC Class 10.  Sequential Read (50 MB ) = 19.7 Mb/S.  Sequential Write (50MB) = 15.9 Mb/SVery substantial increase in Write speed for a cheap card like this..  Highly recommended."

column3117: Solid Value. Just what I expected.
column3118:
I ordered this card after reading a bunch of reviews on high speed SD cards, with the expectation that I would get a good card at a good value, and that it exactly what I got.The first thing I did was test the card with both of my flash testing programs including h2testw. I have had too many 'fake' E-Bay cards lately.My worst of 3 tests is as follows:  Transcend 16GB sdhc class10ser#Test finished without errors.You can now delete the test files *.h2w or verify them again.Writing speed: 14.6 MByte/sReading speed: 18.0 MByte/sH2testw v1.4This result lands it solidly in the class 10 group and exceeds min test requirements.This is faster than my Sandisk Ultra (12.2/14.8) by a little and it is a larger card, and faster than my 8GB Kingston class4 (6.8/9.6). This is the fastest SD card I have personally tested.I immediately recorded my Daughters College play, all 2-1/2 hours of it, on my Casio H20 high speed camera and the card work wonderfully. Videos and 40fps stills and without issue. No problem at all. I still had 4 GB left when it was over. That was nice not having to swap cards.Overall purchase experience is very good with a very good product so far."

column3135: Depends on what you use it for

Works fine to capture pictures on my new Canon 60D. But it chokes on the full HD movie mode , even though technically the class 10 specification *should* mean it would have no problem. I've also had another class 6 Transcend card that I used on an older Sanyo XACTI HD 1000, and that one had issues too, prompting the camera to warn me of 'insufficient card speed ' . I'm staying away from Transcend for anything related to HD video, which means that I'm staying away permanently because having one card in a camera that can do both 18 MP stills and Full HD Video means I can't use the video component of my HD-DSLR, at all.I should have known better than to think they somehow could output cards that cost half to one third that of leading manufacturers with the same specifications.Goodbye Transcend, hello SanDisk."
20101106"
column3138: DESTROYS DATA -- after working fine for just long enough to fool you!
column3139:
SUMMARY:DO NOT BUY THIS CARD UNLESS YOU WANT TO PLAY RUSSIAN ROULETTE WITH YOUR DATA. Card worked fine when I bought it, but malfunctioned within the first 400 photos -- malfunctioned so badly that some very technical tools were needed to recover anything at all, and some photos were still permanently lost. Recovering the data requires the attention of a serious data recovery expert or someone with substantial technical knowledge and lots of time.DETAILS:I made the mistake buying this card for my camera right before a long trip overseas. It worked fine on the first few dozen shots. I didn't see any improvement in speed over my trusty 1.5-year-old Transcend 8GB Class-6 card, but that was most likely because the camera itself (Canon EOS Rebel 1000D/XSi) could not write images any faster than that (full-size JPEG, continuous shutter mode, roughly did ~2.5-3 images/second on both cards, with no slowdown after the first few shots).200 shots or so into using this card, I get a sudden mysterious message from the camera when I try to take a new shot -- Card Format Invalid (never saw it in the previous 1.5 years on this camera with 3 other SDHC cards). I look around for a bit, and discover that turning the camera off, pulling the card out and putting it back in is enough to clear the error message, and the previous photos are still visible.I then make the mistake of assuming the problem is just that -- needing to 'reboot' the camera when the card is acting stupid, and nothing else. Over the next 200 or so shots, this problem comes up every 50 shots or so. Then, after yet another 'reboot', I notice that the camera's playback function is only showing the last 30 photos!!!  Yet it shows that there's only 5.7G of space left on the camera -- the other 2G+ _should_ be taken up by the photos I've shot thus far, but the playback doesn't show them.And this happens in the middle of a trek through the Peruvian Andes, several days' walk/horse ride from the first village with electricity, let alone a computer (with lots of once-in-a-lifetime shots on the camera). I pull this card out immediately, plug in my backup card, and wait until coming back to civilization to take a look at the card. Sure enough, the card is severely corrupted -- the directory listing is showing a bunch of folders with weird-character names, and only the last ~30 photos are visible from the computer, too!RECOVERY SUGGESTIONS:Hopefully you'll read this before buying and will not buy this piece of junk card. If you had the misfortune of running into the same problem and losing your data, read on.I have now had time to examine what was left on the card, using tools that are not easily usable to people without substantial technical training. I've managed to recover over 90% of my photos, but this was NOT easy, and I suspect that even some shops specializing in data recovery from failed disks may not know how to get your data back -- this is NOT as simple as just undeleting a file!Non-technical instructions:1. As soon as you see the FIRST error involving the card format, turn off the camera, pull out the card, and copy all of your photos to a different device (computer/harddrive/whatnot). The earlier you stop using this card, the safer your photos will be.2. As soon as the first problem happens, move the little plastic slider on the side of the card to the 'Lock' position -- this will prevent anything else from being written on the card, which lowers the risk of what's left of your photos being overwritten.3. If you see directories (aka folders) with weird names when you plug this card into a computer -- or see a huge number of photos missing when you look at them on the camera, take the card out IMMEDIATELY, and take the card to a data recovery shop or a technical expert willing to look at the card in depth. Give them a printout of the explanation below.Technical details:At least in my case, the filesystem was indeed somehow damaged, perhaps by the camera deciding to write over the location of the root directory somehow. I took a full disk image of the card, and operated on the disk image only (there were no read errors when making the image, FWIW). Somehow I was lucky enough to have the original _subdirectories_ \DCIM and \DCIM\100CANON survive on the card intact even though the root directory structure now pointed to a different, new, place on the filesystem as \DCIM.I found the location of the old 100CANON directory on the filesystem by searching for one of the filenames I knew would exist in the old directory, like IMG_7000, across the whole disk image.I then edited the filesystem (yea, with a hex editor!) to have the new \DCIM directory point to the old 100CANON subdirectory. See the Wikipedia article on FAT32 for a reasonably easy reference on how to find the 4 bytes that need to be edited, and how to calculate the correct updated value.Mounting the edited disk image (with Linux's 'mount -t loop'), the directory was intact, and all but about 5% of the photos were completely intact as well -- the remainder must have been overwritten after the directory structure got corrupted. Depending on how long it takes the user to notice a problem, of course, much more damage could easily happen to the original data.Here's one easy hack to see how much you can hope to recover, if you're recovering camera data. The same trick may be useful for locating the JPEGs if the original image-containing directory is no longer intact (good luck with recovery then! I thankfully didn't have to do this). Take any image produced by the same camera, look at its JFIF headers. My camera leaves the string 'Canon EOS DIGITAL REBEL XS' in two places in every JPEG it creates, early on in the JFIF header. Search for that string across the whole filesystem. If there's, say, 500 hits, that means you can hope for [easy] recovery of at most 250 photos -- any photo that is missing the JFIF headers will be missing the first chunk of the file, and will make it very hard both to find _and_ to reconstruct the remaining data, if any, into a usable JPEG (I have not tried to do this, at least, and it seems very hard)."

column3186: Slower than Class 10, but a good price
column3187:
Be prepared that this card is falsely labelled and does not meet Class-10 specifications.Class 10 means minimum sustained write speed of 10MB/sec for a card in a fragmented state.Brand new, streaming write, this averages below 4.8MB/sec, with spikes and pauses throughout.I tested with the default format, FAT32 reformat, NTFS reformat.  Writing files from Windows, and formatting a Truecrypt volume gave roughly the same results.Small files write fine, because they're buffered on the card before write, even when windows write cache is disabled.Compare this to cheap Class-6 Transcend Cards which get about 5.5MB/sec sustained with very little pause.So, if you want good performance, pick a SanDisk card.If you want cheap, bulk storage with low I/O needs, then this card is acceptable."

column3210: Depend on what you will use it for ...
column3211:
The 'C10' is for 'minimum sustaining speed' of 10mbps. The sustaining speed is critical if you're using for HD camcorder. There is other brand card that is also c10 but it costs more (2x) for its print of 30mbps on the card. It leads consumers into thinking that the higher price is worth for the 30mbps. However, the 30mbps is the 'burst' speed. Burst speed is critical for HD camera and for doing copies. I have a HD camcorder and I'm very satisfied with this card after many hours for recording. I bought this card to do 100% of recording so it is the right price. I would buy the other high price brand card of 30mbps if I will do a lot of picture taking. The bottom line is to buy for the purpose of your usage."

column3264: Beware if you are not sure your device supports SDHC
column3265:
I purchased this item, hoping to get a whopping 8GB for my Canon PowerShot A620 camera. Unfortunately, the camera refused to work with the card at all. It would not recognize it, format it, etc. Nothing. I was totally stunned, frustrated, confused. After much research, I learned that not all SD cards are created equal. the High Capacity SD cards (SDHC) do not work with devices that support only the basic SD cards, such as mine. Unfortunately it was too late for me, since it was questionably beneficial to return the card for a refund given the amount I paid for it, the cost of shipping, etc. It would be nice if there was a big warning message on the product page, 'This card may not work with older SD card devices.'I suppose it's a very good card, but since I cannot use it, I have no idea. Thus a neutral 3-star rating."
20100911"
column3268:
The class system of sdhc cards is supposed to give you the MINIMUM write and read speeds for a given card. A class 10 card should write at its slowest 10Mb/s. This card did not go above 8Mb/s. My class 6 Kingston card can write at this speed. Don't be fooled by the class 10 rating. These cards don't live up to it. You'll notice that no respectable brand sells class 10 cards because they know that is a high standard to hit. Save your money for a cheaper and more reliable brand."
20100911"

just got this card today and tried copy files onto this card and copy back to my mac and check what the speed is.i was very curious since this card is $5 difference from class6 of the same brand.i also have transcend class6 card, so i compared the result.class10: write 13.5mb/sec, read 18.5mb/secclass6: write 8.5mb/sec, read 15mb/secon wiki says [Class6: 48Mbit/s (6MB/s)][Class10: 80Mbit/s (10MB/s)], so it's about right.the reason i got class6 card 1st was there was 2,500 review whereas 35 on class10 card, so i was not sure getting this one.took 100s of pictures today and seems working fine.still there's faster card like sundisk 30mb/s which probably ideal for more heavy video shooting, but even my class6 card can use it to record fullHD video from my canon t2i no problem so far.only problem i would say is many canon camcorder 2009 model or older doesn't recognize class10 and see it like class4 card or something low, and doesn't let you record FullHD mode. canon doesn't seem bother updating firmware for those old models, so if you are getting one on sale or used, make sure the compatibility of the card.anyway, other review saying this card is slow is not ture. it is standard class10 speed"

column3360: Transcend vs Sandisk of equal price
column3361:
OK. this card was around $47 for a class 10 16gb. The other card i bought was a Sandisk class 10 8gb for the around same price. If your looking for a good card, with more gigs for your buck, the Transcend is well worth it."

20100623"
column3382:
Received mine today, although I ordered it from another site.Speed:I noticed that EVERYONE is saying that this card doesn't meet the Class 10 specification standards. So when I received mine, I was VERY skeptical and scared that this card wouldn't meet the standards. The first thing I noticed was that the packaging on this card was not the same as the one in the pictures section. There was no promised speed of 16MB/s write and 20MB/s read. At the bottom, it says Reduced-Plastic Packaging. This really scared me.When I opened it, the very first thing I did was go to the Transcend Product Identification Website ([...])to see if it was a genuine product. After inserting the S/N and the Model Number, the website gave me the results I wanted to get, genuine. Next I plug it into my card reader (SanDisk MicroMate SDDR-113) and put in a 3GB file into it. As it was being copied into the card, I saw that the write speed was a pretty solid 14MB/s write. Although this is slower than the 16MB/s write on the picture, I didn't mind because my packaging didn't promise 16MB/s. Then I copied the same file from my card to my desktop and got sold 18MB/s read. Again, this is lower than the 20MB/s read on the picture, but since it's not promised on my packaging, I didn't mind.Next I put this card into my Canon Rebel EOS T1i and did a continuous 25 second shoot. I compared it to my SanDisk 4 4GB Ultra II Class 4 SDHC (which, using the same method as my Transcend, has a tested 9MB/s write and 10MB/s read). This is where some of my disappointment came from. Both of these cards gave me 61 pictures in 25 +/- .5 seconds. Even though the Transcend has a tested 14MB/s write vs the SanDisk's 9MB/s write, they both had the same results. The settings I used was shutter speed of 1/40, aperture of f4.5, ISO 100, image quality of Large and Fine and WB of fluorescent.Reliability:I gave this a 5 star because I have yet to take enough pictures to really judge it. So far, all the test pictures I have taken aren't corrupt. I recorded a 2 minute and 10 second 720p30 video without it stuttering or having the video to stop for the buffer to finishing writing the video to the card. I was able to play back the video and the video was not choppy at all. Colors were good and sounds were good (but I have no idea if this has to do with the card).Price:I got this for $19 FS from another site, but the price on Amazon is not high either. For a Class 10 card that exceeds it's specification, this is a good deal!Overall, I think this card is amazing. I believe it is a hit and (or?) miss. I was one of the lucky ones to get one that works the way it is supposed to. As some other people have said, maybe it's your card reader that is bottle-necking your card. Maybe it's because you used the front USB ports (which is what I did). Maybe your USB controller doesn't support Class 10 cards.I'm not sure what it is, but my card reader came with my SanDisk Ultra II and my front USB ports gave me reasonable results. Good buy.Here is the picture of my packaging: [...]"
20100619"

you pay for what you get, slow unreliable, buyer beware. False marketed not even close to class 10!!! my old kingston class 4 is faster than this class 10."

column3391:
I thought the Class 6 SDHC cards were quite an improvement over the previous class.  Now, this Class 10 is truly amazing.  I use it with my Nikon D90 and it never chokes - not for continuous 4.5 fps or for shooting video.  I have a 2nd one for my Canon A720 IS P+S camera which I use a lot to shoot videos.  Again, the card never chokes.  I use Large files, (8 - 12+ MP), plus jpeg and/or jpeg + raw.  Never any problems.  This Class 10 SDHC just does what it needs to do and doesn't get in the way of all that I do.  Nothing more to ask of the card.  Reliable, efficient and very fast!  And the price?  Try finding a better one for less! I couldn't.  This was/is the best there is -- at least at this present time.  I highly recommend this SDHC for anyone who needs this type of reliability, memory, speed."

On a use-only basis, this seems to be a great product. I have purchased other Transcend memory in the past and never had a problem. Unfortunately, the company that provides it for Amazon treats it and the customer very badly. They simply drop it in a thin polyethylene bag with no protection and send it bulk (as in junk advertising) mail. For that they charge $4. I was lucky, it was still in one piece when it arrived. Clearly the $4 is at least 75% profit. If you are willing to gamble on receiving a broken SDHC card, then the price is good. However, if you want to be certain you get one in good condition, this supplier is not recommended."

column3433:
I got 2 of these cards.  I have a Windows 7 tablet, along with 2 old MP3 players, and a newer, cheap mp3 player with speakers.  I wanted these cards to run on the Windows 7 tablet, and hopefully, the MP3 players.First of all, this card comes pre-formatted in the 'exFAT' format, which I have never dealt with before.  I looked at the formatting options, and this card can be formatted in NTFS or exFAT.  So you cannot format this in FAT32 format in Windows 7.  Well, Thanks to a tip from O. Shamayev, I did a websearch on 'forcing fat32 format on SDXC card' led me to a free utility that does the trick, and I now have a 64GB SDXC card that's in fat32 format and works on all my devices, even my 5 year old Cowon D2 mp3 player!It works great!  I'm currently transferring about 32GB of data to the 64GB SDXC card, and it's taking about 40 minutes.  Speed is good for me.  I'm using one of these cards in my tablet, and have the second card loaded with music and it works in all my mp3 players!Highly recommend this card for the price!"

I wasn't looking to use this in a high performance DSLR that can shoot RAW and JPEG simultaneously.  When I purchased a digital camera at a local brick and mortar store, they gave me a 4GB SD card that was class 4.  I didn't want the write speed or capacity of the SD card to be an issue for recording video.  This card serves my need perfectly at a very affordable price and is a good value.  I do not think this card will meet the needs of someone who uses photography for a living, but for a casual photographer it is perfect. I think the 32gb is the best value though I bought 3 of those and will be buying 2 more soon! Hope this helps! God Bless Everybody!"
20120224"
column3739:
We have been using these cards for over two years now in our Canon EOS Digital Rebel T1i.  We also use these cards for our daughter's Canon point and shoot.  We have purchased the 8GB card in the Class 6 and Class 10, 16GB in Class 10 and 32GB in Class 10.  There has never been an issue with any of these cards that we have purchased on Amazon.  Maybe it's luck of the draw but we have been extremely happy with how these cards have performed.We shoot in RAW and occasionally shoot HD video (720P).  The maximum number of shots that we can fire off before the buffer fills up is 9.  There has never been an issue with jitter while shooting video; it has always come out clear and smooth.  We aren't getting out our stopwatch to time the transfer from the card to the laptop... for 400 pictures it took less than 10 minutes to import into Aperture.  For our DSLR, the 8GB card holds about 375 photos, the 16GB holds about 750 photos and the 32 GB holds about 1,500 photos.Folks, with memory cards this cheap, why are you re-using them?  We purchased a few Pelican cases (0910-015-110) to hold our cards as we have finished using them and simply load a new card instead of clearing an old one and re-using it.  As of the time that I am writing this, it costs $9.99 for 8GB of Class 10 memory, $15.98 for 16GB of Class 10 memory and $37.98 for 32GB of Class 10 memory.  For prices that low, we are not recycling our cards; we are buying new ones and storing the old ones.If you would like to register your cards with Transcend, you will need to get the retail packaging as the Amazon Frustration-Free packaging does not include a registration number.As I said above, we have been extremely happy with these cards.  We will continue to purchase them and recommend them to friends, family and colleagues."
20120223"

column3756: Almost 60 GB Available to Both of my 2-year old Laptop's Built-in SDHC Card Readers (Older Laptops Beware)
column3757:
Just a quick review to hopefully clarify a somewhat maddening issue.It seems these 64 GB SDXC cards can be Fully utilized by the built-in SDHC Card Readers of fairly modern laptops (2-years old).I have two Lenovo Windows 7 IdeaPad laptops and they Both can write 59.4 GB to my 64 GB SDXC card formatted as it was delivered (exFAT I recollect).  It has been repeatedly reliable and rather fast for a garden variety built-in SDHC card reader.For older laptops, the OS or card reader may very well be limited to only seeing the first 32 GB, as many have said.NOTE: For Windows XP users with a fairly modern computer: There is a Microsoft Support Download which will enable XP to utilize these large capacity SDXC cards.I hope this is helpful to someone."

column3765: Excellent Write Speed with USB 3 Readers
column3766:
I've noticed a lot of people who've said write speeds are slow on this card. Keep in mind that a LOT of things affect write speeds. If you use a card reader built into a printer you will get slow speeds. If the card is close to full you will get slow speeds. If you have a cheap card reader IT might be the bottle neck.I recently purchased a USB 3 card reader, as my new motherboard has a couple of USB 3 ports. WRITE speeds for this card went through the roof. I downloaded a 4 gigabyte movie to the card, [keep in mind big files transfer faster] and it averaged 21 megabytes per second. That's twice the rated speed of the card. [Rating is based on minimum write speeds--Class 10 cards should give you no less the 10 MB/sec if there are no bottle necks.]The next movie I loaded was about the same size, but the card was nearly full and had had a lot of deletes, so the file was being scattered all over the card. Basically the equivalent of writing a lot of small files. The speed was about 11 MB/sec. This card provides great value. You just have to accept that there are technology limitations that are not in the card maker's control."
20120222"
column3769:
Transcend products are cheaper than SanDisk products for a reason.I struggled trying to transfer files (less than 4MB) from my computer to this card. I continuously received 'Delayed Write Error' or ''The disk in the destination drive is full. Insert new disk to continue'' (when the disk was 2% full) messages and could not transfer the files. I reformatted to NTFS, but still had the problem. I assumed the card was defective, so I returned it for another one. The same problem persisted with the replacement card.Forget trying to contact Transcend support ...they are completely unresponsive (they probably know they can't solve the problems or are so overwhelmed with complaints that they can't respond).I figured: 'Well, SanDisk is a little more expensive, but they have good reviews. I might as well try it.' Received the SanDisk card and, within an hour, I had transferred every file, that had failed to transfer onto the Transcend card, onto the SanDisk card without a problem.I guess you get what you pay for after all."
20120222"
column3772:
A lot of room and speed for the money. Bought for my T2i now I have room to shoot RAW. Best buy I could find!"
20120222"
column3775:
A dollar per gigabyte? How can you go wrong? For the most part, you can't. But if you do high-resolution continuous shooting, it's going to slow you down. With a 16 megapixel Sony Nex-5n set to store RAW plus fine JPEG, the camera fires off a quick half dozen shots, then slows to about one per second. With fine JPEG only, I got 10 or so shots in a 1-second burst, then about 2 per second thereafter. Standard JPEG is only marginally better.The good news is that I never shoot burst/continuous, so this isn't an issue for me. These cards are so inexpensive you could just file them away when you fill them and leave it to future generations to sort out your images.The other good news is that I can shoot HD video (60p) on these cards with the Nex 5n or on my Canon Vixia HF M40 camcorder. That's good enough for me."

column3781:
Have you ever been in an airport or mall and found yourself walking in one direction when everyone else is walking in the opposite direction?It's eerily like driving the wrong way on a freeway. ('If we're going north why does the direction indicator on the rear view mirror say 'S'?' 'Yep, that's odd.' 'Then how come the signs on the highway are pointing the other way?' 'Yep, that's odd.' 'What are those lights coming towards us?' 'Yep that's odd.') Not that I have ever driven the wrong way on a freeway, but you get my point.This is my third Transcend SD card. First I bought the 32 GB, then the 16. Most people upgrade; it looks like I'm going backwards. The card works as anticipated. No bad sectors (yet). So far, not disappointed with Transcend. Their prices are great, and if you buy your card during a sale (which IMHO is the only time to buy a card) then you will usually get value for your money.Now I must leave you to look for a 4 GB SD card, I guess after that a 2 GB card is next....do they still make 64 KB cards?"

The sd card i bought is now unable to read/write/format by camera/computer. and all pictures I took while I was in CA and Yosemite are gone now, literally forever, I don't have any backup in my laptop.The card, as I mentioned, is fast and cheap, but hey, if this is all you want, go for it and my best wishes that you won't end up like me because the Transcend don't have the stability we need.all the best,Zhiliang"

Before I start to use it in my vacation, I download some free speed testing tools and they all showed much slower access speed compare to 'class 10'.My Canon HF100 (yeah, a little bit old, but still a HD camcorder) report both cards can only record in XP+ mode, that's 12MB/s. column3865:
I bought this card because I found out that I needed faster memory cards to record full HD on my new T3i. I read a few reviews on this card and thought that for the price it would be worth having a big memory card so I can record a lot on it. This memory card can hold approx 96 min of full 1080p footage from a T3i, according to the T3i manual its 330 mb/min. So the size and for the price it is good. T3i require class 6 or above to record HD effectively. So I purchased this card as well as a smaller 16 gb from the same brand. This card does well for photos but can be unreliable for filming. Its not as fast as it claims to be and I have had a few times where my camera has stopped recording automatically because how slow the card is, I would classify this card more close to a border line class 6. For the majority of the time recording is fine on this, but if you want something more reliable I would suggest going with Sandisk class 10. This is a good card with a lifetime warranty if you can deal with the occasional hiccups with this card, this could be a nice back-up card after your nicer card gets full. Its a good buy for the price."

I gave these cards to my son who has a Sanyo HD camcorder. They work fine with my son's camcorder. At least for now. I suspected these cards' write speed is no longer fast enough for my Canon camorder which required only class 4 memory card. Very disappointed."

column3897: Amazon is sells damaged goods and won't make refunds!!!!
column3898:
Just before leaving for a month-long trip to India in late Augsut 2011, I purchased two of these cards from amazon.  Upon receiving them, I find out there is a recall on these cards which are defective. I could not get anyone at amazon's 'customer service' to address the issue, so I had to buy a more expensive card locally to take on my trip.When I get back, Amazon says I missed the return date and had to send them back to Transcend, which gives me the runaround.  Now, 6 months later I still have these useless defective cards that amazon sold.Amazon has absolutely terrible customer service and it is nearly impossible to contact them.  Amazon sells damaged merchandise and refuses to give refunds.  Transcend manufactures damaged merchandise and refuses to honor the warranty.Beware of dealing with either."

column3901:
I received this card today for use with a Sony A55 DSLR. Before using it in the camera I ran the same speed test utilities on it that are shown in the product images (ATTO Disk Benchmark and Crystal Disk Mark)The SD card didn't meet class 6 specs (Minimum recommended for HD video) let alone the class 10 rating listed on the it. I requested an replacement and hope that the new one will work as advertised.Update 2/16: Received and tested the replacement card. It tests almost identical to the first card, well below class 10 specs (at least they're consistent). On a side note I tried the card on several devices, I even went as far as doing an overnight read/write test and it worked fine just not up to the class 10 rated speed."

This is my second card that I've ordered from Transcend this card is as good as any of them. I ordered this one for my GoPro Hero 2 and it has worked as good as any. It's fast and has had no problem being read. If that changes I will return here and update my review. The other one I purchased is a compact flash and been using that in my D700 and D3s for over a year with no problem. All these cards have the chance for failure and they will.. Some faster then others. So back up your work often and keep it moving. So with that in mind (they are going to fail) then why spend more? I have Scan Disk cards and none has failed yet. I also payed more for them then I did for this one, and both are still working fine. Here's a helpful hint 'treat them like they are delicate, because they are and all should be well'1)When not in camera put them in case it came in or aftermarket one2)Never touch the metal contacts3)Never place contact down (especially on metal surface)4)Never get it wet5)Always format/clear in the device your using it in Not On Computer!Be Well!!"

column3936: Great for Stills, not good for HD Video
column3937:
I bought this for my Cannon T3i and while it works great on still photos, it is too slow for the video capability of this great camera. My video would stop recording at 14 seconds because the card could not be written to fast enough to clear the buffer. HD video uses a lot of data and needs a high speed card. Look not at the 200X, 400X speed, but the millisecond transfer rate. I got a 95ms card and it never bogs down. I got some 40 ms cards and they work fine as well. In HD video speed is king, so make sure the card you buy meets your purposes."

column3964:
I remember when I got my Nikon D50 SLR 6 years ago that a 1 GB card was about $70.  I choke thinking how cheap they are these days in comparison and come in class 10, but all technology comes down in price.  Since they are so inexpensive these days I find myself transferring my images onto my laptop and external HD and then keeping the card as my 'digital negative' in a SD card case as a final backup, esp. for trips such as Alaska, Hawaii and other more expensive trips that I'm not likely to take again.  There's no way I could do that back when cards were so expensive - I'd be broke with all the traveling I do.  Since I use the card this way I don't want an 8 GB or higher SD card - for me anyway that becomes too much storage and I'd rather keep it short and sweet so 1 card equals 1 trip.  4GB is a lot of images even on the highest resolution setting.  It may not be all that much for those using it for videos, but according to my newest point and shoot that does 1080 HD recording it gives between about 25-30 minutes which is still pretty respectable.  I don't use the video function so it's not a concern for me, but I think that amount of time would be more than enough if I ever did want to record something.I like Amazon's frustration free packaging as well.  A welcomed change to having to fight with packaging."

column3973:
A class 10, 8gb memory card for this price? And the reviews on this are great. I haven't done speed tests or anything, but haven't had any trouble recording full-HD recording on my camera (1080p), which is really all that matters to me. 8gb is an ideal size; I don't want one card that's 16gb, prefer 2 that are 8. That way I can put one in the computer and have the other in the camera at all times. Take one out, put one in. You won't forget your memory card that way. Of course if you plug the camera directly to the computer it won't be a problem then, either... Ok, well if one goes bad you'll still have one. Ha. Did you know SD cards are waterproof (up to 72 hours in 1 meter of SALT or fresh water), withstand temperatures from -13F to 185F, can withstand drops up to 16 feet, vibration proof, survives being run over by a 5 ton delivery truck, and magnet proof? Oh, and x-ray proof, and can withstand 500Gs of shock. in case that matters. Just found that out, kinda good to know if I drop my camera 16 feet in Alaska (most of the year) and the memory card pops out and into a puddle, gets run over by a truck and after all that I forget that it's in my pocket when I get an x-ray, it will still be ok. I wonder if it would survive being swallowed... If you get the urge to test that, you might wanna try it with a microSD card. Just a thought. If you have incriminating pictures on your camera, it might be good to know if you can swallow it and it'll survive. Just sayin."

column4014: Mishap in shipping, quickly resolved by Amazon!

I had ordered a couple of LED monitors and some PC peripherals from amazon, and I had ordered this 32gb SD card separately. They bundled it with my other orders though, and when it had arrived in a really large box, it wasn't there. I checked the delivery status online and it said it had been delivered. So I got in touch with Amazon through live chat and they said it was nothing to worry about, because they would overnight *another* one to me!I was surprised to see they would send me another one no questions asked, but at the same time relieved. When you package large things into a very large box, I assume they must have forgotten to put it in the box or something. I'm glad it was resolved quickly though!Another reason why I love shopping from Amazon and their representatives!"

column4017: Not sure this is a Transcend! ?
column4018:
I have 3 other Transcend 32GB SDHC cards (exactly same specs as this one). The others, however, DO fit into any device I put them in. But this one that I just ordered does not seem to want to fit. It does feel a very very slight bit thicker than the other Transcend cards that I have. I tried it in multiple devices (camera, PC, video cam) and it feels like I have to force it in. Once in, it won't 'spring out' like the other cards do, it seems to get stuck every time, in every device, and I had to use tweezers to pull it out!  So beware on this one -- I am not sure whether this is a true Transcend SDHC card. If it is, maybe I just got a bad one (or reject/second)."

column4140: Cheap, do not buy, terrible warranty support
column4141:
Cheap, terrible product.  First time I used it and put it into my card reader, the plastic seam that seals the top part of the plastic cover to the bottom completely split, and basically left me with a memory chip and a broken cover that was in two pieces. I have used many different cards and many different readers and never had this happen before.  I didn't push the card in too hard either, it was normal use.  Obviously a defect in the plastic cover.  Sent it back for warranty replacement, and they refused to replace it and sent the original back saying it was broken due to misuse/abuse.I will NEVER buy a Transcend product again, and the more people I can encourage to do the same the better.  I bought this card because it was the cheapest even though I wasn't familiar with the brand, and it cost me.  I'll stick with a better name brand from now on."
20120121"
column4144:
I ordered this SD card paired with a new Canon camera.  The product was recalled 2 weeks after it arrived due to a bad controller that would not allow transfer of large data files off of the card.  Never mind the fact that we bought this card to photograph the birth and few first weeks of life of our new baby.  2 weeks after the recall, images on the card started corrupting.  I returned the card to Transcend, and they said they would not honor the product recall because our card was 'damaged.'  It is not clear to me how this happened, but apparently their crack team of technicians opened the card and found a hairline fracture in the memory stick which voided the warranty.  Their logic was, yes, we sold you a defective product, but since it was somehow 'more broken' after I bought it, they would not honor the replacement.  Their customer service manager was less than helpful.  In fact, he took extra time to educate me on the nuances of the electronics business.  'You don't understand how business works.  You can't buy a Cadillac from a dealership and when the catalytic converter gets recalled you smash the hood with a sledgehammer and expect to take the car back to get a new one.'  He must have learned this analogy in B school before he took his customer service position at Transcend.  This is no Cadillac, don't buy it."
20120120"
column4146: Pathetic, should've trusted the other reviews

The device arrived in its true to form no hassle container.  However it also arrived at half the space!  I purchased the 64GB version and when I plugged in the SD card I was only able to utilize 27GB of space (even with the recommended SD formatter).  A complete waste of my time and the sellers.  Hopefully yours won't be a lemon too.  DO NOT BUY!"

column4149: Who cares about speed, when the shell it's in is junk...So is the warranty
column4150:

Class 10 means 10Mb/s in transfer speeds from the camera's image buffer which equates to be able to take about 3 - 5 pictures a second. column4312:
There's nothing quite like a data storage device suddenly dying to give a sick feeling in the pit of one's stomach.  This Transcend card worked fine for about 5 months as I continued to take photos and video using a Lumix ZS3 camera.  Every few weeks or so I would pull the card out, backup my latest photos using the suppled Transcend USB card reader, then return the card to the camera.Suddenly, and without warning, the card went dead the day after Christmas.  This was not just a file or FAT table corruption commonly reported here.  The card simply became non-responsive, giving an 'Memory Card I/O error' in the camera or similar error when inserted into the USB card reader.  All the usual tricks of data recovery were useless since the card was simply not responsive to gain access to the stored memory.  Fortunately my loss (because of routine backups) was only about 20 pictures and perhaps one video.  Even with my regular backups, it could have been a whole lot worse.In looking at Transcend's warranty policy, I was not surprised to see bold type language that excludes data loss or recovery.  Rather, Transcend refers customers to a 3rd part who charges hundreds of dollars without any guarantee of success.  Odds are few people would be willing to surrender a card full of personal photos just to simply get a twenty dollar value warranty replacement."
20120108"
