I purchased this card for a new digital camera; unfortunately the product literature did not state the camera would not function without an SD card in place; silly me, I presumed the camera's on-board memory would allow it to function while I did more research on memory cards.  Since I was in a bit of a time crunch as a result - needed the camera to record an upcoming vacation and family events - I needed it FAST as well.  The card is quite fast; this Canon supports a 'burst and combine' option for producing the best pictures in low light, and I noticed no lag at all between the pictures taken in the burst (3 shots), and minimal lag as it assembled the images into a single one for viewing.  The capacity is such that I can take as many pictures or videos as I like at the maximum resolution the camera will support, and I don't have to worry about running out of memory.  All in all, I have been very pleased with the card and the purchase experience."

20120107"
column4330:
I have a variety of class 10 cards, many Transcend, SanDisk, and others. The digital properties of this card are average in my experience. I would not hesitate to recommend this card based solely on digital dynamics (speed, compatibility, etc.). The physical properties of this card are below average. Compared to SanDisk extreme (or some other brands), this card is very fragile. The plastic construction is not well suited for frequent insertions and removals. Many SD readers are designed with shallow card sockets, which means about half of the SD card is external to the device, and unsupported. If the person inserting the Transcend card is not extremely careful, the card will flex or bend, severing electrical connections inside the card. This renders the card useless. There are other brands of SD cards that are much stronger, less flexible and less likely to be physically damaged when inserted into the device. If the card is not frequently inserted and removed, I would not hesitate to recommend this product. Transcend will not replace their SD cards if they fail from flexible bending. This is a very completive market, and for a few dollars more, you can purchase a card with much stronger physical properties."

The great part was the price when combined with free standard shipping. Cheaper than Ebay auctions and other sources. However it shipped Fedex Smartpost and the package stopped tracking and was lost at the handoff to my local post office. That was bad as I needed it for Christmas Eve. Once I realized my order was lost, and I had called Fedex twice, and the post office 3 times with no result I emailed Amazon. The representative quickly offered to not only reship, but sent it overnight UPS at no cost! I had my new card 12 hours later from 4 states away. column4519:
I bought this card for my Canon T3i. I have used it for stills and video. I am happy with the card overall, and will order Transcend again for stills. Video however left me wanting more. Just seems slow to say class 10.With stills I shoot RAW. I went through up to 5 shots in continuous mode before having the camera slow and then up to 15 shots before it stopped to let the buffer empty. I was trying to shoot the hummingbirds around our house. As a result I lost a few good shots. The write speed was not all that good for action shooting. However, still shots were clear and perfect in single mode, and the card had no problem keeping up with write as long as the shutter released was pressed for each shot.With video, even thought it is a Class 10 card, I was having trouble with stuttering. I could not shoot more than 3 minutes at a time without running into pausing issues on the developed video, and eventually spent the money and bought a Sandisk Extreme card to replace it for video and action shots.I am happy with the card over all for my still work and portrait shots. I will order this one again to use for that purpose, but if you are looking to catch that perfect moment when you son kicks the wining goal, you don't want to slip on the shutter release, or have the buffer fill up on you. I did include some images I managed to capture with this card though, and I would recommend it for hobbyists and again for portraits, landscapes, and students."

But this transcend is very close to its specs. It says its read speed is 20mb/s and its write speed being 16mb/s and its very very close to those marks on my tests. This places it at one of the top ones on my list for the overall price and performance. Now with that said I wouldnt recommend it for a high end SLR that has super high speed shooting(like a few others also state) but for an overall point and shoot digital camera its going to be perfect. column4677: OKAY but NOT BEST FOR CANON DSLR VIDEO MODE
column4678:
Camera stops working at random times! The 'writing speed' or the rate of which the disk takes in the video is not fast enough. You need at least a SanDisk hd video memory card. I think it has to be a minimum of a class 20 or something. I just basically got a 64 gb card for photography only now which is a HUGE waste of money. I bought it for video because the ad said it could be and other reviewers seem to have some success with it. But it is not true. It fails about 5-10% of the time!Update to situation: I found out it was because the camera was sorta running out of space, but its not like at 45 minutes boom! - you're outa space. Its like 30 minutes(totally approximating) starts to get unreliable and gives the message movie has stopped recording without any explanation. FOr the longest time, I thought it was a stupid default feature on the camera. I was trying to change the settings. Then I looked online and found that it was actually the card. Then I tried deleting a few recordings and it made things much better. I suspect other higher class cards will not cut out so unpredictably until it truly runs outa film. I have the canon t2i. Hope this helps another canon dslr user.Peace!"

column4863: Transcend 32 GB Class SDHC 10: real life speed test
column4864:
I have a Transcend 8 GB SDHC card that works pretty well for my application. So I bought this 32 GB card to give it a try. There were some reviews saying that it is not really a class 10 card in terms of writing speed. So I did some quick tests. I copied a folder containing 766 files of various sizes and total 20.4 GB onto the card. That took 40 minutes and 59 seconds --> average 8.5 MB/sec. Then I copied 355 files (9.4 GB). That took 18 minutes and 8 seconds --> average 8.9 MB/sec. So in both tests the write speed is a little bit shy from the nominal 10 MB/sec but not too much off. Reading back and binary comparing with the original files from the first test took 28 minutes and 21 seconds. So the reading speed is 12.3 MB/sec."
20111211"

column4893: Trusty little performer - fantastic value for ample pixel warehousing and foray into HD videoing
column4894:
This was purchased fr amazon's Black Fri sale for all up about AUD20 including shipping.Initially purchased for the Lumix LX5 which I was quite keen to acquire but have since dropped the idea. Am now using this as a backup for mum's new Canon Ixus 220 HS for high definition videoing which can now be liberally done without the nagging fear of rapidly running out of memory space.  I have read about some 32GB purchases which despite being class 10 were disappointing in access speed performance.  This I cant vouch or dispel at this stage as the card is currently 95% empty and it needs to fill up before the speed or lack of will manifest - nor do I have a comparison eg SanDisk equiv.  Will update this space so pl bear with me until all is clear.I picked the 16GB over the 32GB for the simple rationale being if anything goes wrong with the card, 2x16GB is better risk management than 1x32GB for data recovery.In summary, for simple usage - this card represents fantastic value for pixel warehousing."

column4921:
I purchased this card for use in my Canon t2i 550d SLR camera.  Given this is only an 8gb card, it will not hold a significant amount of photos or video however for short shoots or short videos it works perfect.  Using an class 6 card the 1080p video would seize up after about 5 seconds however a higher speed card allows video to record smoothly with no limitations.Rapid fire photos are also easliy done with this card. With a class 6 card, it would constantly say 'busy' after firing off several photos however this card is quick enough to save images quickly.Benchmark testing rates this card just over 16 mb/s writing and just over 20 mb/s reading.  To be rated a class 10 card it must simply write at 10 mb/s therefore this surpasses other class 10 cards for a reasonable price.I would recommend this card for a multi-use inexpensive SD card.  For high quality photos on an SLR camera you may, however, want to purchase something with a bit more storage (32GB) so you do not need to frequently delete photos."

When I say distorted, I mean the picture would have discoloration saturated throughout the picture, sometimes it even looks like the colors flipped to the opposite color spectrum as if it was a film negative.  I also made sure it was the card and not the camera by using other brands of SDHC class 6 and class 4 to snap many sample pics, and none of them had issues.To me this is unacceptable since I had taken many pictures, only to come home and find out a portion had to be deleted.  Ironic thing was the previews from the camera looked fine, but the full picture downloads were not, so not sure why this is."

column5056:
I am always worried about getting the wrong card for my camera. Think about it... all your memories for a prolonged period can be lost in seconds. With so many brands out there it is hard to choose a card or gauge quality. This is one of multiple Transcend cards I have owned throughout the years and so far none have ever given me any issues in terms of recording or retrieving images and movies.As with all cards I would always suggest these do not become your primary storage medium. After every shoot I try to unload all images onto my computer and of course create backups. Furthermore, it is a great idea to format these in your camera regularly. I do it after every shoot but it is probably overkill. Like in a regular drive corruption can build up and formatting clears that up for you if it's not a hardware issue.Overall very satisfied with Transcend and this speedy 32GB SDHC card."

column5122:
Esta es una de mis peores experiencias con un Producto. Compre estas memorias el 3 de agosto. Y cuando las recivi empeze a filmar con ella en mi 60D de Canon. Para mi sorpresa despues que tengo 1 hora grabada de Boda. La tarjeta me dio un error, y perdi toda mi informacion. Intente recuperarla con mil programas pero perdi la informacion. Pense que solo era una de las 4 tarjetas que compre. Para mi sorpresa son las 4 que tienen problema. Perdi 5 trabajos que realize con esta tarjeta, tuve que devolverle el dinero a mis clientes y tengo dos meses escribiendole a transcend y aun nada. La verdad que las compras de estas tarjetas me han traido muchos malos ratos. Si fuera usted yo diera un poquito mas y comprara una tarjeta Sandish o otra marca pero nunca le recomendaria comprar esta tarjeta. De verdad que estoy muy decepcionado!!!!!! Lo mejor de el caso es que vivo en republica dominicana. Que ahora tengo que pagar un envio para que me la cambien y me sale mas caro que lo que me costaron las tarjetas."

column5127: Its an SDHC card. it works. it was cheap.
column5128:
They work. That's all I need from a memory card. anything else you need to know about the SDHC card format you can find on wikipedia, so I really only have one thing to say to you:When it comes to class number, remember this:1. If you're not using this for your hd camera, than class number (these are 10s) does not matter2. A class 10 WILL give you better hd video than a lower class sd card will.3. A class 10 MIGHT give you better lapse time between being able to take pictures with your digital camera, but that difference only goes so far and will only be noticeable if you're taking hi-res pics (like 10mp or higher) or video.Hope this helps!"

column5130: Works fine for Canon 60D HD Video
column5131:
This inexpensive Class 10 Memory Card works fine with Canon 60D for HD Video at 1940x1080 30.  I previously purchased the 32GB Transcend and 16GB PNY that did not work for HD Video.  These two cards would only work at 640x480 60 and for photos.  Previous to this purchase, the only memory cards that would work for HD Video were an 8 and 16GB Panasonic Class 10 Gold Cards I purchased for a significant amount more than any of these inexpensive Class 10 cards.  Until finding this card, I thought to do HD Video I would need to buy only the Premium cards.  I have bought another Transcend for HD Video.  Guess the 32GB just processes slower due to larger capacity or was just a bad copy."

I am going to return it to amazon."

Speed is as stated in the Crystal DiskMark screenshot.  I'd give this 4.5 stars if I could, because it's slightly smaller than another brand's 16 gb card I have.  The formatted capacity for this card is 15.0 gb.  The other card's formatted capacity is 15.4 gb, so you do get a little more there."
20111122"
column5158:
This review pertains to both the 16GB and 8GB cards which I purchased at the same time.I've been using Transcend cards for about 3 years, and now they've become my standard for my digital cameras. This is the first 16GB card I've gotten, and it's just as fast as the 8GB. It's faster than two other manufacturers but I'm not knowledgeable enough to say why.My camera is capable of 8 frames per second in burst mode, and the card handles that very well. (I have a 2 GB card that doesn't, but it shouldn't be expected when the card will fill up in a half-day's shooting.) And, on the download to the computer directly from the camera, I downloaded 131 high resolution (approx 6MB each) in 54 seconds! That's fast, fast enough so that I may never use my card reader again.I do not take movies though I have the capability. This card will be strictly for high res picture taking. So, why 16GB. Well, I figured that I wouldn't have to start a new numbering system for my photos next year. I've found that with 8GB cards, once I reach 10,000 photos in a year, the camera and the card seem to start over and I have duplicate numbers. This might not be a function of the card, and if not, I'd actually appreciate someone telling me that.Btw, the 8GB Transcend card has probably been formatted 250 times in the last year. Not one problem with it, and I fully expect that the same will be true with this one."
20111122"

Then I decided to try it on my Nikon D90 DSLR using continuous shooting outdoor with good daylight, here are the results before it consistently starts to slow down noticeably (3 tries with each card)Transcend Class 10 / after 18 to 20 shotsSandisk Extreme III Class 6 - 20MB/s / after 40 shotsI would not hesitate to keep this Transcend for normal usage, like a tablet, but when it comes to continuous photography shooting, I am keeping my Sandisk. Just my 2 cents.* UPDATE 12/16/2011Recently bought the Sandisk Extreme Class 10 - 30MB/s, now the camera is consistently shooting 60+ shots before slowing."

I've since sent it to numerous people trying to get the pictures off and no one can do it.  I few weeks later I got a recall letter on it.  ALL my pictures of Hawaii GONE.  What a piece of crap SD card.  So disappointing.  I will never buy a transcend card again.  I've heard similar stories from several tech-savvy friends that this is a bad brand."

column5211: Unhappy with quality and RMA process
column5212:
I purchased this card in January, 2011. It worked fine until a couple of weeks ago when the write-lock switch fell out of the card after ejecting it from my card reader. Looking at it closer I found that the side of the card where the switch was located had split. The card is less than a year old and was well cared for. I followed Transcend's RMA process and sent the card to them. I received it back today with a note saying that there was damage to the card and that they would not replace it. I guess they are referring to the manufacturing defect that caused the card to split. In any case I suppose I should be happy that I'm just out the money for the card after reading some of the other reviews. It would have been worse to have lost data as well.I'll spend the extra money for SanDisk and Lexar from here on out. Lesson learned."

Using my old 8GB Class 4 card, shooting Large JPG and RAW, it would stop shooting after 6 shots and then take a while to transfer everything to the card. With this 16GB Class 10 card, it stopped shooting after 7 shots, but then only took about 1 second to transfer everything. That was a big difference. However, testing the card with Flash Memory Toolkit, it only reads/writes at about 1.6 MB/s...nowhere near 30. It satisfies what I'll be using it for."

20120515"
column5304: A card that is actually class 10
column5305:
I looked at a lot of different SD cards before I bought this. A recurring theme I found was that there isn't an independent ratings body for flash media and that some manufacturers didn't accurately report the speeds of their flash.I tested this card by writing a 1 GB file using dd on my Sheeva Plug and found that it had a 10.6 MB/s write speed. The minimum write speed for a class 10 card is 10 MB/s, so you'll get what you pay for here."

column5359:
It's an SD card.  I've never found much to distinguish one card from another, and the thing I care about most is reliability.  I've been using two of these cards in my Nikon D7000.  The camera has two SD slots, and I use a 16 GB card for jpegs in one slot, and a 32 GB card for RAW in the second slot.  So, for every picture I take, I get a jpeg and a RAW file.  I've found this convenient.  It allows me to send quick snapshots to people when I'm on vacation, and when I've got more time I can tinker with the RAW images.  The Transcend cards have worked perfectly for this arrangement.  They're fast enough such that I never have a problem with buffer space (and note that 18 megapixel RAW images are large).  Most importantly, the cards have never failed.  They even work reliably in my MacBook Pro, which has an idiosyncratic built-in card reader.  I wouldn't spend more money for another card, you'd be paying for some fancy adjectives, like 'extreme,' but I don't think you'd get any greater functionality.  The Transcend cards have been perfect for my purposes."

column5394: Major failure: Transcend HC 8GB memory card
column5395:
In May, 2011, we went on a Moscow - Volga - St. Petersburg tour, equipped with two Canon cameras - mine an SD 780 IS, which works perfectly. I purchased and installed a Transcend HC 8GB memory chip in my camera. The camera appeared to work normally - taking at least 550-600 shots with plenty of memory left - I even took 2-3 minutes of video.Unfortunately, when downloaded to my home PC - only about 160 pictures were available to view - I was stunned to say the least - this was a once-in-a-lifetime tour - the photos are irreplaceable.I called a local camera shop, which said they might be able to  recover the rest. Well they recovered another 200 or so (charged me about $45), but the first three days of our vacation's really interesting photos, they could not recover.However, they had a recommendation, another company nearby, which does digital work for the Department of Defense, might be able to help. I called them and they quoted a price of $500 dollars over the phone to recover all my photos - if unsuccessful there would be no charge. Money doesn't grow on trees - I'm mulling it over. But I highly recommend NOT buying any Transcend memory chip"

column5407:
I purchased these through J&R Music and Computer World via Amazon a couple of months ago as preparation for my Paris vacation.  I owned a Class 6 Transcend 8GB card for a long time and it was fast and never had any problems, so I figured I should get two of these class 10 cards as backup as i wasn't going to be bringing my laptop with me.Despite these being class 10 and therefore supposed to be faster, the ones i received are SLOWER than my class 6.  I tested both cards and took various photos around the house and noticed there's a distinct 2 second or so lag after i take a photo.  With my class 6 card, I can take a photo and immediately change to view mode to look at what i just took a pic of.  With the class 10 card when I do this, I get a message saying something like 'recording, please wait' for around 2 seconds before my photo appears.  When taking photos too, with the class 10 there's a very obvious 2 second lag after each photo.I kept both cards because I was paranoid i'd run out of space on my class 6 card and i already tossed the packaging (returns seems to require original intact packaging?  how does that work if i obviously have to open it to test the card? O__o ).  Ultimately my single class 6 8gb card from years ago was plenty for my trip so these two cards were a waste purchase...probably giving one to mom when i buy her a new camera later.in any case, these cards are oddly far slower than my class 6 transcend 8gb cards.  I haven't used it long enough to know if there are any other issues (such as ones described by other reviewers that it corrupts after a few months of usage)."
20111031"
column5409: Perfect for GoPro and other HD video
column5410:
I bought this for my GoPro HD Hero, which accepts a maximum of 32GB SDHC.  They say that you only need a class 4 card, but the faster transfer rate of the class 10 is well worth it when taking videos that end up being larger than 2GB each.At $45-$55, this is good buy.  It's a reputable brand and won't leave you hanging like some generically branded cards might, and you also can be sure that when they say it is a class 10, you will be getting class 10 speeds.  It's also a great price for the performance... Other 32GB class 10 cards can cost over $100 and deliver similar performance.I can't speak for much other equipment, but my GoPro HD Hero and my Canon T1i will shoot full HD (1080p) continuously with this card with no interruptions.  I would imagine that you'll find the same thing with just about any other piece of equipment.No reason not to buy, unless you don't like a good value?Note: This is not a problem, but the card tends to be a bit 'fat' for some slots, which may mean that it will get stuck or show resistance on the way in/out.  This wears down and isn't an issue after you use it for a while."

column5419:
Product was recalled by Transcend, so I sent it back along with the paperwork that they ask for. Alas, the envelope was damaged in transit and arrived at Transcend without the memory card. Now Transcend refuses to process my return, saying that they explicitly ask customers not to send in returns in paper envelopes. Somehow, I feel cheated. First, they sent me a faulty card; then, I dutifully wasted time in filling out the return forms that they require, not to mention physically going down to the post office to mail in the return. And they still expect a disgruntled customer to spend extra money to get a fancy padded envelope or box to package the return? Enlightened businesses that treasure their customer base will put their clients beyond reproach in cases like this, and not come up with a mealy-mouthed excuse to deny all responsibility. Do not expect me to ever buy another Transcend product, and I urge you not to either, lest you find yourself having to deal with the same deplorable customer service."

column5427: The wonderful Class 10 Speeds and 16 GB Capacity!

What a deal! A perfect SDHC card needless to say Class 10 = a maximum read/write of 10 MB/s which is just great so far! Great price as well! As I tell everyone who asks me about memory cards though: You MUST check with you device's manufacture's specifications! This card will NOT work in anything that can take a SD card! Your device must be able to accomadate a High Capacity type SD and your device must also support at least 16 GB capacity to use this! If your device fails to meet one of these criteria do NOT buy this you won't be able to use it!BUT: If your device can do both then get this Class 10 card! You will not be disappointed with its amazing speed! Atan amazing price need I say again!"

column5434:
I purchased this 16 GB SDHC card for my camera for an extended trip to Europe. Unfortunately, I did not download the images onto my computer on a daily basis because after 3 weeks of traveling and accumulating hundreds of photos and a few videos I suddenly got the following error message, 'memory card is not formatted'. The card was not recognizable on my computer and after discussing the issue with a data recovery expert I was told that the likely cause was a physical failure of the card and that it would cost me between $350 and $450 to recover the data! This is after a one time use of this card! I should have heeded the advice of other reviewers on this site who have had a similar experience with Transcend cards. If you value your pictures and videos, do not buy this card."

column5497:
Average read speeds ~4.5MiB/s, bursts up to 6MiB/s. Write speeds exactly half that. Did not use any synthetic benchmarks, which inflate read and write speeds by 2-3x. Benchmarks produced by reading and writing large FLAC files for an hour on a factory-formatted new card in a PCI-attached reader, replicated on a _Transcend_ USB reader.This reflects the testing I've done on Kingston and Patriot 'Class 10' 32'GB' (29GiB) cards--except those are actually somewhat faster. Not 'Class 10', which should guarantee a _minimum write speed_ of 10MiB/s; but faster.Hasn't anyone ever wondered why these cards cost the same--or even less--compared to Class 6 cards?Returning to try my luck with SanDisk--which costs half again as much; hopefully for a good reason."

column5505: Be careful with high capacity cards
column5506:
I bought this same card off of Ebay for $30, for my Canon rebel t2i. It worked fine for my first 200 pictures or so. and then in the middle of a photo shoot it started playing back the images fine for a minute or too, and the next time i played back the same images it would show a question mark and say it cannot play back the image. i took 400 pictures during the shoot, and thought they would at least show up on my computer later and that it was just the card was being weird with the camera. wrong. 360 of those pictures were corrupted by the card and are not recoverable to my knowledge. i made sure it was compatible with my camera before buying it.  I am sticking to several 8gb cards now instead of one 32gb. I lost all of those photos and i suggest if you are getting 'cannot playback image' to stop using the card before you lose all of your pictures. its also VERY slow when saving images, whereas 4gb cards will save them quickly and get back to the main camera screen fast."

column5677:
Looking for a cheap card to dedicate to my laptop's unused card slot, to be used primarily as a Win7 ReadyBoost cache - no complaints.Multiple test runs w/H2test show 15.6-16.8 MB/s write, 17.4-20.9 MB/s read.  Read typically is 20.x, but on occasion drops to the low end of the range for duration of a test run - I suspect this is interaction with the Readyboost cache.  I have several other Transcend SD and SDHC cards in cameras, and have not had a failure yet.  There are faster cards, but for the price, this is a good value.As for Readyboost, dedicating 1/2 the card to a 4GB cache noticeably improves program load time and other operations that involve loading large #'s of files. Visual Studio goes from launch to ready in sub-second times for medium size (10-20 dependencies) projects.  Debugging with all Win32 symbols local goes from 10-15s loading the primary DLL sym files to 2-3s max.  Not a substitute for more RAM, but worth the minimum pricepoint.  Using the Class-10 card is a significant improvement over earlier tests with smaller Class-2 and -4 SD cards.  All tests done on a i7-2630, 4GB RAM, 7200rpm non-SSD drive, Win7 pro."

column5691: Terrible company, unreliable product.  SAVE YOUR PHOTOS, DON'T BUY THIS CARD!
column5692:
Transcend is an unreliable company, with tech support that will make you want to jump out of the nearest window.  The reviewer who said, 'Do you like playing Russian Roulette with your images?!' had it spot on.  DO NOT BUY THIS CARD UNLESS YOU DON'T MIND LOSING ALL OF YOUR PHOTOS.I bought the 16 GB SD HC card before a very important shoot.  Near the very end of the shoot (having shot less than 400 frames total on this BRAND NEW card) the playback suddenly stopped and displayed an error message telling me it could not read the format.  I took the card home where my computer could not read the images through the camera.  I bought a card reader, which was also unable to read the images.  I downloaded Transcend's recovery software, which did nothing.  I called their tech support, and got a woman who spoke poor English and got ANGRY with me when I politely said, 'I'm sorry, can you please repeat that?'  She was apparently the only tech support person on staff that day, because I called back a few times as fix after fix failed, and always ended up with her.  She also seemed upset that I owned a Mac.  Really??  How many professional photographers do you know using a PC these days?  She informed me that I could send the card to their factory in Taiwan where I could wait 3 months to see if they could recover the images.  3 months??  I have a client waiting for these images and a contract to get them to him within 2 weeks!  I asked for my money back.  They won't refund my money, they'll only replace the card!  Why on earth would I want ANOTHER card from a company who can't explain what happened to the last memory card I bought, and can't be relied upon to remedy the situation in an acceptable way?  They made me feel like I was the bad guy for asking them to be accountable at all.  At no time did anyone apologize for the disaster their product had caused, nor offer any real solution for my situation.Don't trust the good name of your photography business or the importance of your family photos to this company!  Replacement or not, I'm cutting my losses and replacing all of my Transcend cards with the far better rated (and higher quality) SanDisk.UPDATE: I was finally able to speak with a manager who was much better grounded and informed than the woman who I had initially spoken with.  He told me they are able to reclaim about 85% of images sent to their recovery center.  He was also far nicer, and at least pretended to care about my situation.  He said I would have to send the product back to Amazon for a refund, which I will be doing.  Conclusion:  10% of cards, according to the number of review here, have failed.  They can recover 85% of images if your card is one of the bad ones, if you have 3 months to wait.  For me, it's just not worth the risk."
20111006"

column5698:
I bought this to use in a Bushnell Trophy Cam 466 Black LED game camera for observing wildlife and noticed the video was choppy on 720 mode.  How could this be ?  It's a 'Class 10' right ?  I have the 8GB SDHC card and bought it from Amazon.  Well I tried a piece of software called H2testw (google for it) and it shows this card writes at 4.3 mb/s and reads at 13.6 mb/s.  That isn't very good.  My regular Sandisk bulk white label 8gb class 4 writes at 4.28 mb/s, but my Sandisk Ultra 4GB Class 4 writes at 10.4 mb/s and reads at 15.1 mb/s...all of these results coming from H2testw.  So just be careful  if you are planning on using this card for video I would look for something else.  If you want it to store stuff like documents, etc, I think it may be a decent buy, but the 'Class 10' rating is VERY MISLEADING"

I bought this card mainly because it had good reviews and a good price.  You can't beat Amazon in price and shipment speed.  However, I had used this card twice when it started malfunctioning. I have a brand new Canon T3i and I bought this card to be the primary card in my camera.First, the camera would tell me to 'insert the card'.  Then, after 5 seconds it would be normal again.Then it said that the card was not recognized, to change the card or format it.  I turned off the camera to check the card and put it again just to try and it would be OK again.It started malfunctioning at a Champions League soccer game, so I was scared that I would lose my pictures, so I borrowed a card from another friend's camera and put it in and kept taking pictures.When I got home, I tried accessing the pictures using the memory card reader to no avail.  I tried using the camera to import pictures, did not work either.I even used recovery software but it kept saying the card was a 1GB unformatted card.After this I started doing research and found out this cards are flawed.  They have a manufacturing problem and they are recalling this cards.  I also read that some customers in Germany even sent the cards to Transcend to have them recover the images but they have not gotten anything back yet.I have contacted them and I'm still waiting for a reply.  I will update this review after I get some kind of response."

As long as I downloaded from the camera and not from a digital reader it was fine.  I am fairly computer savy and built my own last year currently running on W7 64 bit pro.  The original card reader would not recognize my Transcend 16G card in W7 where it had with all the other 2G cards with my now retired Nikon D50.  I bought a new card designed specifically for the newer SDHC cards and still W7 would still not recognize the reader...  I then used another HDSC 8GB card and it worked fine....  Amazon gladly gave me a replacement and I had the same issue so I returned both of them and stuck with the four 8GB cards from a Nikon reccomended vendor and have had no issues since... What is really confusing is that I know a lot of people have used the Transend 16 & 30 GB Class 10 card for their D7000's and not had any problems...  Is it the 64 bit W7, should I use the 32 bit funtion or just bag it and stick with the Nikon approved cards??  Input is requested... column5850: Piece of trash -- don't waste your money
column5851:
I purchased one of these for a new Canon camera.  It fit very tightly into the slot, but at first appeared to work OK.  I did a high level format but not a low level format.  I took a few pictures to test the camera and then put it away.  I used on vacation and discovered that some pictures taken and stored on the card could not be read by the camera-it gave an error message.  I tried to do a low level format, but the card could not be formatted--again gave errors.  I finally got it out and put it into an external card reader.  The end of it broke off in the reader, and I had great difficulty getting the pieces out.  The reader could not read the card anyway.  So it is a total loss.  Don't waste your money on this brand--get a Kingston or other reliable brand instead.  Also-be sure to do a low level format on your card when you get it, to make sure it is working ok!!!"

column5863:
A month into owning the card, and about 16GB into the 32Gb capacity, I'm still very happy with this.  Bought it for my Canon 2Ti, for which it can hold 7900+ pictures in Large compressed format.  Half that for uncompressed.  Card is made in Taiwan, better than from China given Taiwan's experience with memory.I've noticed no issues with speed, and just copied over 4GB into an external hard drive in 4 minutes.  I don't have any software to test actual speed, so I'll just say that I haven't felt any issues when shooting.  One issue I've encountered is when taking video, my Canon will sometimes 'timeout' in a few seconds of shooting.  I have no idea if this is an issue with the speed of the card, or something with the camera's features.  My guess is it's a camera feature, but thought I'd point it out anyway."

Card die on the second day after two day of vacation. Enough said never buying transcend again. Gonna go back to sandisk"
20110917"
column5869:
Bought the card for our new Sony Cyber-Shot DSC-HX5. Shortly after we got it, Amazon informed us of a recall on the card, which supposedly had to do with downloading very large files (e.g. a very long movie). I contacted Transcend who gave me RMA info to replace. I asked if there were any other issues. They wouldn't respond. Sent several emails. No response. Dead silence. 'We don't care' customer support at its finest.Had no choice but to take the card on our trip, planning to take only small videos anyway (so as not to hit the problematic size) and then return for replacement on the recall when we got back.The card just went dead, absolutely corrupt, will not even reformat (neither in the camera nor in a PC). Abso. Lutely. Dead.We have now lost our entire vacation's photos, movies, and another important video we just made for a non-profit group we volunteer with. This was all mere minutes before I was to download them, for safety, onto my PC.G O N E.I am having trouble finding the words to describe just how small my opinion of Transcend is."

I bought this card because of the sheer number of reviewers who stated it was a great card and obviously it was much cheaper than its sandisk counterpart. I used it in my Canon 60D and when I went to copy the photos across to my computer a heap were missing. I put the card back in the camera to see if it was just the card reader but alas the images weren't there anymore.I stopped using it and I'm waiting till I get back from my holiday to see if I can use some data recovery software to extract the corrupt files. In the meantime I've bought the 32gb sandisk and had no problems with it so far.Perhaps I'm one of the few who have received a dud as the numerous positive reviews certainly swayed my initial decision to buy this. This experience has soured any chance of using a Transcend for something as valuable to me as my photos."

This is a class 10 card. I use it with my SLR and I can see that response times are quicker compared to a slower card I had, both when used in the camera and when used with my pc to transfer picture. I personally never use the 'lock' switch on the card so I wish they would leave it out. Maybe3 it can reduce the price a bit? who knows. It also may add to the durability of the card by having less moving parts (an SD card should have moving parts at all I guess).Anyway, it's a great value for the money. Big enough capacity for SLR (>1000 photos) and quick response, for a decent price."

20110912"
column5932:
The same factory churns out class 2 and class 10 devices... the 'brand quality' is your trust on them to separate and correct label (ever wondered why all SD labels are silk or adhesive?) acording to the measured speeds. cheap brands will brand high class if some small sample pass the minimum speed... great brands will test all cards.transcend used to be a good brand.The card i received is a class 2. see pic i uploaded for the abysmal writing speed graph.i can't find any lot number or anything to make this more informative. anyway, just don't blindly trust the packaging. Test every and each card.For precision test use something that writes directly to the device (avoiding filesystem overhead). If you are not that knowledgeable in that area, just copy a huge (1/2 the capacity of the card or some 3Gb, whichever smaller) movie file and measure the time, the number will get close enough."
20110912"
